title: my boyfriend 32 years older
story: My boyfriend is  years older - people think hes my dad but the sex is greatJessica Hockings, , met -year-old Dermot Murray at work and the pair quickly became friends - but despite more than three decades between them, their friendship blossomed into much moreJessica says they have a great sex le Image: Kennedy News and MediaByHelen Le CaplainJessica TaylorReal Le Features Writer:,  Feb |commentsA carer who is engaged to a man  years older than her says people think theyaposre dad and daughter - but they have an amazing sex le. Carer Jessica Hockings, , met -year-old Dermot Murray at work last February after heaposd had a fling with one of her friends. As the pair spent time together, taking late-night drives and walking Jessicaaposs dogs, they quickly fell for each other. By April, they were in an official relationship - but hid it from their loved ones at first for fear of judgement. However, the secret-keeping proved too much for Jessica who just wanted to hold Dermotaposs hand in public, and she soon announced the relationship. For more of the news you care about straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here Jessica from Mumby, Lincolnshire, said: I didnapost want to know [Dermot] at first. I donapost have a lot of trust in men so to me it was very daunting. But the lady I worked with on the evenings had a fling with him for a couple of months then as a group of three [we] became really close friends. Then me and Dermot went into our own little friendship world. She described how their relationship began to progress slowly. As the shts swapped over we used to have a cuddle and as it progressed I used to stay behind when everybody left and just spend time with him.  Weaposd then spend more time together when we used to go on late-night car drives, Jessica said. She added: It started off like a dad daughter relationship, it was a gradual transition from that to a romantic relationship. Although Jessica was initially apprehensive about the age gap, she no longer sees it as an issue and the pair have officially been together for  months. In fact, the -year age gap means Dermot is best friends with Jessicaaposs -year-old mum - and the pair even watch TV together when Jessica is at work. And their dference in age doesnapost make a dference to their sex le, which Jessica says is great. She said: We have a great sex le. Physically itaposs very good, heaposs gentle and always asksIaposm alright.  The pair are often mistaken for dad and daughter when theyaposre out but brush off the judgement. The last time I went to hospital someone asked aposoh is this your dad whoaposs brought you apos Iaposm like aposno itaposs my partnerapos, Jessica explained. It doesnapost bother us because we know that people might not understand. Family and friends have been very supportive, which I was surprised at. I think the only worry that there is is because weaposre in dferent letimes - when he retires Iaposll still be working. The pair have recently been shopping for engagement rings - although Dermot hasnapost officially popped the question yet. Still, Jessica is expecting a proposal from her beau soon - and sheaposs even had her ring finger inked with a heart tattoo with Dermotaposs initial.  When itaposs going to happen I donapost know but heaposs said itaposs definitely going to happen at some point, Jessica said. I got the tattoo because weaposll be getting engaged at some point and he means the world to me. She added: Iaposve never had a relationship where Iaposve been treated properly or loved like he does - itaposs all new to me. Itaposs just really nice because heaposs old-fashioned in the romance way and I love that. We used to write notes for each other, the odd gt now and then is really nice. Certain things he does for me now is just really sweet like heaposll run a bath for me, or make me a drink or dinner - stuff like that just means a lot to me. If he leaves for work early in the morning, which he sometimes does, he leaves a note for me on the bed or I leave him a note for when Iaposm at work. Jessica said sheaposs happier than ever with her relationship, despite the large age dference. Jessica said: Going out with an older man I find is so much better than [someone] my age because they have more le experience and heaposs just so mature and loving. To anyone who thinks  years is too big a dference, I would say as long as they treat you well the age shouldnapost matter. title: brexit eu rules changes imports
story: Are you ready to import from the EU into the UK  Pasta firm has genius idea to helpAny business importing from the European Union into the UK must now be able to prove their meet the new rules of origin requirementsAdvertorialByDave MastersDigital Commercial Editor:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb Rules of origin are an important trading requirement. If you sell goods to the EU, or buy goods from the EU and bring them into the UK, you need to be able to prove that they meet the new rules of origin requirements to access preferential tarfs. It’s vital you understand the new rules to keep your business moving. To benefit from the preferential tarfs, you must have proof that any goods you import from the EU originate there, or any goods you export to the EU originate in the UK. Proof of origin can either be a statement of origin completed by the exporter, or evidence of the importer’s knowledge of where products originate. If you cannot prove the origin, you or your EU customer may be liable to pay the full rate of customs duty and could face penalties. Andrew Macleod, founder of London-based restaurant brand Emilia’s Crafted Pasta, explains that imports from the EU are vital to his brand: “We import ingredients directly from Italy, including special cured meats, cheeses, drinks and alcohol. Each of our suppliers is hand-picked.”  Has he had to make any changes to his business now that there are new import rules in place  “Yes – of course we already knew the origin of all the goods we import as we source everything carefully. But we’ve trained two of our managers on the rules around importing, so we know that we have staff in house who are well versed in the process.”  And having successfully navigated the changes, what advice would Andrew offer other businesses that import  “We found using a customs agent really helps the process run smoothly, but it’s equally important that you understand the rules yourself,” he says. “It’s not too late, and the gov.uk site has lots of valuable information.”  You must be able to prove the origin of any product you import You can choose to work with a freight forwarder or courier To benefit from preferential tarfs, you must be able to prove that any goods you import originated in the EU Note:you’re moving goods between Great Britain and Northern Ireland, rules of origin work dferently. Contact the Trader Support Service for up-to-date guidance and support. FIND OUT WHAT YOU NEED TO DO. Visit gov.uk rules-of-origin

title: couple 90s finally marry after
story: Man proposes during girlfriends heart attack as pair in their s to wed after  yearsMo proposed to his we-to-be Jo while she was having a heart attack and the -year-old love of his le finally decided to take the plunge after years of turning him downMo proposed to Jo while she was having a heart attack - but after calling  Image: SWNSByLauren BeavisMichele Theil:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |comments A couple in their s who have lived together for  years are finally getting married - after he proposed while she was having a heart attack.Maurice Benton, , and Joanne Orris,  - better known as aposTeam Mo and Joapos - decided to tie the knot during the medical emergency at their home.Jo agreed to take the plunge while she was in the grips of a cardiac arrest after years of turning down Moaposs regular proposals.And she later joked that he was so shocked by her acceptance it almost caused him to have a heart attack of his own. She has now recovered from the health scare and the couple are busy making plans for their big day next month. Do you have an incredible story to tell  Email webnews@mirrorJo recalled the proposal, saying: I said to [Mo], aposI feel so illapos. He said, aposI canapost do anything for you, so Iaposll ring .apos Then he came forward and knelt down. He said, aposIaposm sorry I canapost take this pain away from you. Will you marry me apos Iaposve always said no in the past, but my heart attack made us realise perhaps we havenapost got so many years left, so weaposll get married after all. The heart attack led Jo to feel like le was short and being married for the time they had left together was the best choice. Iaposd always said we were alright as we are, living aswe were a married couple. Itaposs been a big joke that Iaposd rather be a mistress than a we, she added Jo, of Curry Rivel, Somerset, joked: When I said yes, I think Maurice was so shocked, he nearly had a heart attack as well. Weaposve been laughing ever since. And it means there wonapost be any problems with the taxman! When the vicar and registrar conduct the wedding in the coupleaposs home on Saturday, March , it will be Joaposs third nuptials - she orced her first husband, while the second died in his s.  Get the news you want straight to your inbox every day.to one of the Mirroraposs newsletters here Jo, who has two children, six grandchildren, six great grandchildren and two great great grandchildren, added: Everyoneaposs really thrilled for us, although most of our friends and my cousin said they thought we were already married. Mo, who has two daughters and five grandchildren, said: Iaposll still be her slave, doing all the washing and ironing. Joaposs not so mobile, but fortunately, sheaposs got a sharp brain like nobody . It was about time she made an honest man of me. Mo and Jo became known as the Perfect Strangers when they sent anonymous letters and parcels to British troops serving in the Iraq War. They were also made honorary Gurkhas for their fundraising efforts for members of our armed forces. title: couple whose businesses were ruined
story: Exclusive: Couple whose lestyle was ruined by pandemic earn fortune from sexy OnlyFans videosCharlotte, , and Bear, , were struggling to pay their bills when their businesses were wiped out by the coronavirus pandemic. Now, they are earning a fortune through OnlyFansCharlotte, , and Bear, , at their home in Gloucestershire Image: Reach CommissionedByDave BurkeSenior News Reporter:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |commentsA couple whose businesses were decimated by Covid are jetting off for a new le in the sun after raking in thousands each month sharing X-rated videos online. Neighbours in their leafy Cotswolds village are oblivious to how the raunchy husband and we, who have five children, have turned their fortunes around.The pair, who go by the names Charlotte, , and Bear, , were forced to apply for Universal Credit after the salon and construction firm they ran were wiped out by the pandemic. Struggling to pay the bills, they decided to share videos of themselves having sex on subscriber  OnlyFans, and now have a lucrative army of subscribers.Charlotte and Bear now plan to move their family to Greece so they can continue their new occupation in the sunshine.  Charlotte told The Mirror: “We worked all our lives for our businesses, but then the pandemic came along and decimated them. “I had to make redundancies, it was awful. This is a lot more fun for us.” They now upload new videos and images every day and say they were pleased by the response, now making upwards of £, a month. In spite of their success, they said close friends and family were surprised by their new line of work. Charlotte, nicknamed Chots, said: “We were in a position where we applied for Universal Credit, but that’s a long wait when you’re not earning money. “We’ve always had an active sex le, and it’s something we started joking about. At first we thought we’d give it a whirl, it’s something we enjoy doing.” Their hundreds of subscribers may be familiar with them getting saucy in the bedroom, but Charlotte said her neighbours would be shocked. “We live in a quintessential English village, I think they’d have kittensthey knew,” she said. “They’d think ‘no way, they’re not like that, they’re really normal’. We’re quite homely people really.” The mum-of-five said at first it was nerve-wracking sharing their intimate moments with complete strangers, but described the response as “amazing”.  “There were mixed emotions, but people seem to like it, we don’t always take it too seriously and to be honest it’s quite fun,” she said. “We’ve now got lots of subscribers and we have to work hard to keep them. We’re turning it from being a side-hustle to making it a full-time job, we’ve got to put the effort in there.” Charlotte and Bear run two accounts on OnlyFans, with each having around  subscribers paying £. a month. On top of that, inidual users can ask them to make customised videos, for which they pay upwards of £ a minute. Although they’ve told some close friends and family members, most of those around them have no idea about their new income stream - and their children have no idea. “At first there was a bit of shock obviously, and there were a few questions about how it would work,” Charlotte said. “But they thought as long we’re not having complications or bringing in other people, which we’ll never do, it’s ok, they just tell us to stay safe.” But as it is a protected  with age verication, she said she is not worried about their kids stumbling on raunchy footage. “I don’t think it’s something we’ve got to have a discussion with them about,” she said. And she said it has brought the couple - who have known each other since they were teenagers growing up in the Cotswolds - even closer together. “We thought will it interfere with our marriage, but it hasn’t at all, we’ve found it’s a lot of fun.” On Monday they plan to leave the UK behind and jet off to a new le in Greece. “We’re embracing our next adventure, we love travel and prefer warm climates, and we can create content wherever we are. “We’re not making millions, butwe do get a new iant we’re lockdown proof and it’s something we enjoy.” Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON LoveTeenagersDaily MirrorCoronavirus" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily coronavirus briefing with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: dog who spent 515 days
story: Dog who spent  days in kennels and was almost put down finds new homeRSPCA Brent Knoll launched a nationwide appeal earlier this month to find their longest-staying resident a forever family - now Terrier Buddy has settled in very well in his new home with a lovely coupleBuddy has settled into his new home very well and RSPCA staff are so pleased Image: RSPCAByNia DaltonSpecialist Writer:,  Feb |comments Just two weeks ago, a nationwide appeal launched to help find RSPCA Brent Knoll aposs longest-staying dog a permanent place to call home.Thanks to the incredible support of followers across the world, terrier Buddy has found his happy ending and a forever family at last, after spending  days in kennels. The senior dog - who was was almost euthanised by his previous owner - has settled in very well and hasnapost stopped playing ball in his new home.The happy news was shared on RSPCA Brent Knollaposs Facebook page, after the centre were inundated with requests to rehome him, and emails came as far and wide as Canada in the U.S. Buddyaposs new lovely owners spotted him on BBC Points West earlier this month, and took him on a walk before proceeding with the successful application. to ourTeamDogs newsletterfor your weekly dose of dog news, pictures and stories. We are pleased to say that everything is looking just grand! RSPCA Brent Knoll wrote on Facebook.On Tuesday, the centre posted photos of Buddy in his new home with a message from his adoptive parents: Buddy is settling in very well, he hasnapost stopped all day playing ball and going around the field, but he is asleep on my lap now! Regards Mr  Mrs J, we too are very happy! The ten-year-old terrier went into the care of the RSPCA in , after a vet refused his previous owneraposs request to euthanise him because of his challenging behaviour. Katy Darelli, Deputy Manager at RSPCA Brent Knoll, said: This cute lad is an affectionate chap who sadly had a less than ideal relationship with his previous owner. There was a clear breakdown in communication between them and this resulted in confrontational misunderstandings. Buddy began to retaliate to these experiences at which point ownership was relinquished to us after a request for euthanasia was rejected by his vet. Buddy worked hard with behaviourists in Somerset to try and tackle his issues and identy triggers. He came on leaps and bounds, and the team discovered he had an obsession with squeaky balls and enjoyed eating from activity feeders.For more information about how the team are helping transform the lives of animals, and to find out how to adopt a rescue animal in need of a loving home, visit the RSPCA Brent Knoll website. news uk-news first-queues-begin-uk-petrol-"Asda in Kingswood sees queues of drivers waiting for fuelByLucy WilliamsonReporter:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |comments Long queues have been pictured at petrol stations in parts of the UK amid fears the price of oil and gas could shoot up following the crisis in Ukraine.Russia is the worldaposs second-biggest oil producer and the largest natural gas exporter, and mainly sells to other European countries.Pump prices have already been rising as oil edged past  a barrel, but the Ukraine invasion has now seen it jump above . Oil prices typically quickly flow through to what drivers pay at the forecourt.Prime Minister Boris Johnson has already warned that one of the risks of Putinaposs venture is that there could be a spike in... oil prices. However, there is no indication that people in the UK need to panic buy fuel. The nationwide average for unleaded is already a shade under £. a litre, and diesel above that. Experts warn petrol could hit £., over even more,oil keeps rising. This threat of a further increase in price has forced many into queuing at pumps, trying to get the cheapest price per litre in the chance it may rise more in the coming days.  Joe Michalczuk spotted long queues at his local Sainsburyaposs in Winchester today.They had staff directing traffic he told The Mirror.And the queue had built from pm to pm where it snaked around the majority of the car park.It was identical to the petrol panic. But rather smugly today, I have an electric car.According to HullLive, large queues have been spotted in Hull and parts of Lincolnshire.  Drivers were spotted waiting for longer periods to get their petrol at Morrisonaposs, Holderness Road, on Thursday afternoon.In London, one person wrote on Twitter: Long queues at every petrol station this lunchtime on the outskirts of London.Reminds me of the recent petrol crisis. Iaposm guessing many believe the war in Ukraine will increase the cost of petrol signicantly, so they are filling up their cars now   A picture was posted by another driver, who wrote: Queue at Costco for petrol half an hour ago… Looks like the conflict is gonna drive prices up.. I’d shop around.. PREMIUM diesel at Costco, £., at the BP garage near me, £., Morrisons are £. for standard diesel. One driver, who went to fill up at an Asda in Kingswood, said that the scene was “hectic”. People are being urged to consider ways in which they can use less fuel as prices rise, rather than engaging in panic-buying over the coming weeks. title: kate middletons broody wont more
story: Kate Middletons broody but she wont have more children because of Prince WilliamKate Middleton and Prince William already have three beautul children, but while on a royal visit, the Duchess hinted that the family wont be expanding any time soonPrince William and Kate Middleton Image: Samir Hussein WireImageByPaige HollandShowbiz Audience Writer:,  Feb |commentsThe Duchess of Cambridge wonapost have any more children evenshe is broody, she has confessed. Kate Middleton and Prince William have three beautul children, Prince George, Princess Charlotte and Prince Louis.And it looks like itaposs going to stay that way as Kate revealed the Duke doesnapost want any more children. During a visit to Bradford with William in , Kate opened up about the possibility of another Cambridge baby. While chatting with royal fan Josh Macpalce, who excitedly told the royal that he has sent cards congratulating her after each of her three children were born, she revealed that it is unlikely she will become a mum of four in the future - and itaposs all because of William. I don’t think William wants any more, she told the -year-old. Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up .Macplace, who has autism and DiGeorge syndrome, which is caused by the deletion of a small segment of chromosome , held out his arms to Kate, who bent down and gave him a hug. Thank you for the hug, she told him. Josh had travelled with his mother, Sue, , from Blackpool to Bradford, combining a trip to a pantomime with the chance to see the Duke and Duchess. William playfully expressed his concern about expanding the family during the coupleaposs visit to Clitheroe Community Hospital last month.Kate had stopped to take some pictures with families at the hospital including one with couple Trudi and Alastair Barrie with their daughter, Anastasia. As Kate held the baby girl for a photo, the onlookers around gushed, which prompted William to jokingly say: Donapost give my we any more ideas! And when Kate handed the baby back to her family, he said: Donapost take her with you. And while at Copenhagenaposs Childrenaposs Museum in Denmark on February , Kate confessed that being around children made her want more kids herself. While discussing working with young children on a two-day trip on behalf of the Royal Foundation Centre for Early Childhood, she told reporters: It makes me very broody. William always worries about me meeting under one-year-olds. I come home saying aposletaposs have another one.aposHave you got a story to share We want to hear all about it. title: kate middletons sweet message guest
story: Kate Middletons sweet message in guest book at lodge where Prince William proposedPrince William asked Kate Middleton to marry him while on a romantic holiday in Kenya, but before they left the lodge they were staying at near Lake Rutundu, Kate left a message in the guest bookThe couple announced their engagement in  Image: PAByPaige HollandShowbiz Audience Writer:,  Feb |commentsThe Duchess of Cambridge wrote a sweet note in the guest book at the holiday lodge in Kenya where Prince William popped the question. Kate and William met when they were  and both studying at St. Andrewaposs university. They were good friends before they moved into a shared house with other pals, where romance blossomed.Despite a brief split in , William got down on one knee and asked Kate to marry him, whilst on a romantic holiday in Kenya. The couple travelled around the country before heading to Lake Rutundu, which William had decided was the perfect place to pop the question. According to royal expert Katie Nicholl, he booked a log cabin for their stay and the couple spent the day fishing for rainbow trout. Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up .She claims that when they ed to the lodge, William took Kate out onto the veranda, got down on one knee and proposed. The following morning it was time to check out and head home - but not before they both wrote a goodbye messahe in the lodgeaposs guestbook. Kate wrote: Thank you for such a wonderful  hours! Sadly no fish to be found but we had fun trying. I love the warm fires and candle lights—so romantic. Hope to be back soon. She signed off Catherine Middleton. William then wrote: th-st October . Such fun to be back! Brought more clothes this time! Looked after so well. Thank you guys! Look forward to next time, soon I hope. And thereaposs a sweet reason he decided to propose in Kenya.William explained why he picked Africa for the special moment, at an event at Buckingham Palace to celebrate the UKaposs relationship with Africa. He said: The African continent holds a very special place in my heart. It is the place my father took my brother and me shortly after our mother died. And when deciding where best to propose to Catherine, I could think of no more fitting place than Kenya to get down on one knee. And he did so with his late motheraposs ring. Kate and William didnapost officially announce their engagement until the following month. A statement from Clarence House at am on Tuesday, November  read: His Royal Highness Prince William of Wales and Miss Catherine Middleton are engaged to be married. The Prince of Wales is delighted to announce the engagement of Prince William to Miss Catherine Middleton. The wedding will take place in the Spring or Summer of  in London. The pair tied the knot in a beautul ceremony at Westminster Abbey on April , .Have you got a story to share We want to hear all about it. title: nuclear test veterans were more
story: Exclusive: Nuclear test veterans were more likely to have cancer and die, government study findsA study found out that nuclear test veterans were more likely to die. There are now cross-party calls for a public inquiry and immediate compensation, as well as a medalNuclear test veterans who were told to watch atomic blasts have raised rates of multiple cancers Image: Getty ImagesBySusie Bonace:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |comments Men ordered to take part in Cold War radiation experiments WERE more likely to die, according to a government study which has blown apart  years of official denials.Nuclear test veterans told to watch atomic blasts then live, eat, and drink amid the fallout have raised rates of multiple cancers, the research has found. They are nearly four times more likely to die from a bone marrow cancer seen in survivors of Hiroshima and Nagasaki, and more likely than other servicemen to take their own lives. The shocking research proves:HALF the crew of HMS Diana, ordered twice to sail through fallout in , died from tumours Atomic scientists were SEVEN times more likely to kill themselves RAF decontamination crews were FIVE times more likely to die from leukaemia There were more cancers than deaths, meaning some veterans have fought multiple malignanciesAnd despite Ministry of Defence claims servicemen were well-protected, three-quarters were not checked for radiation, while clean-up workers were both unmonitored, and more likely to die from blood cancer.  There are now cross-party calls for a public inquiry and immediate compensation, as well as a medal. Mayor of Greater Manchester Andy Burnham said: “This is all the evidence required to seek a formal inquiry into the issues and injustices that more than , veterans of nuclear testing have faced. It appears to be incontrovertible proof that their service led to serious health issues. “They need recognition and for the government to give them the respect owed to them by acknowledging what they have known for years: they paid a devastating price for their vital role in protecting our country. We are at a critical moment in this journey for justice and we need to see action now.”  His call for speed was echoed by Tory grandee Sir John Hayes, patron of the British Nuclear Test Veteran Association, who said: “There can be no doubt and no more excuses. Based on these facts, we need to act with no delay to recognise these exceptional veterans’ extraordinary sacrice.” More than , men, many on National Service, were ordered to take part in  nuclear weapons tests and  radioactive ‘minor trials’ in America, Australia and the South Pacic between  and . They later reported cancer, blood disease, miscarriages for their wives and  times the usual rate of birth defects in their children, but the MoD spent millions denying war pensions and compensation, insisting there was no proof.  The new research comes eight months before the th anniversary of Britain’s first nuclear test, Operation Hurricane, on October , . It was published without warning on the morning that Russia invaded Ukraine.It looked at causes of death among , veterans compared to a control group of servicemen who were not at the tests. It traced only  per cent, but found three per cent more veterans had died from cancer and two per cent more veterans died from other causes. Test veterans were  per cent more likely than controls to die from stomach cancer or pleural cancer,  per cent more likely to die from skin cancer, and  per cent more likely to die from acute lymphatic leukaemia. There were  per cent more deaths from suicide, and  per cent more deaths from chronic myeloid leukaemia. CML is caused by genetic mutations in the bone marrow. By-products of nuclear weapons, including plutonium- and strontium- are considered “bone-seeking” when absorbed by man, and it is known that they can damage DNA. Stuart Ross, whose dad Archie was a RAF corporal at Christmas Island in  and died in  from aggressive leukaemia, said it was time to released the veterans’ military medical records.  “My dad suffered for years with a layer of skin growing between his eyelid and eyeball, a daughter born with an outsized arm, and a grandson with Down’s syndrome. Then he died within six weeks of being diagnosed with blood cancer,” said Stuart, , of Hertford. “I’ve asked for the blood tests dad and many other veterans had taken when he was on the island, and officials tell me they don’t exist. They’re hidden somewhere. The Defence Secretary must order them to be released to the families. We deserve the truth.” The latest research studied an extra  years of data, and found higher rates for many types of death than were in three previous studies, first ordered by Margaret Thatcher in . The report’s authors at the UK Health Security Agency warned that the MoD could no longer rely on dodgy dose records from the s, saying that there should be no raised risk of death or cancerthe records “accurately reflect the broad levels of exposure”. They added that risks they found should be expected “, in fact, doses… had been much larger than recorded”. The Mirror has campaigned for justice for the test veterans since the s. A MoD spokesman said: As this latest report states, those who participated in the tests continue to show lower levels of mortality overall than expected from national rates, although this dference has narrowed with longer follow-up.We owe a debt of gratitude to everyone who participated in the British nuclear testing programme, they played a valuable role in developing a nuclear deterrent that has kept Britain safe for decades. We will publish a comprehensive response in due course. aposThis isnapost history, it is our daily livesapos Ken McGinley was sent to Christmas Island aged . He later became sterile and developed a rare blood cancer. He founded the BNTVA in , and has now been diagnosed with stage  lung cancer. He said: “This study is proof, but it isn’t the full picture. It doesn’t analyse the sterility, birth defects, or miscarriages, or the number of cancers some of us have had and survived.“It’s time for full disclosure - a public inquiry. This isn’t history, it is our daily lives, and the government must act now to deliver justice before that anniversary.”Ken, , of Paisley, added: “I was treated like an enemy of the state. I wasn’t given my blood cancer diagnosis although it was in my notes, my benefits were stopped, and when my we Alice and I were trying for children, a note was added to our file that the doctors would be ‘very interested in the outcome of any pregnancy ’.”aposTragedy took over mumaposs leapos After The Mirror called for a medal, then-Defence Secretary Gavin Williamson met campaigners in . Widow Shirley Denson, whose husband Eric was an RAF pilot ordered to fly through a mushroom cloud in , walked into the room and said: “So, you’re the man responsible for killing my husband.”Shirley, of Morden, Surrey, had uncovered documents proving Eric was used in an experiment on his plane, and had the equivalent of , X-rays to his brain in just six minutes. He later took his own le after two decades of crippling headaches, saying he couldn’t stand it any more. A third of his descendants have birth defects, including missing and extra teeth.Mr Williamson was so impressed by her that he ordered fresh research. Shirley died before it could be published, in March last year, with the MoD refusing her deathbed plea for a medal. Daughter Shelley, , said: “My mum was a formidable woman. She raised four daughters, and had to deal with the tragedy not just of my dad’s suicide, but his illness in the years before it. It took over her le. “This study proves what she always said, when the government claimed there was no evidence - we ARE the evidence. All those young men who were sent to their deaths, just married, with children on the way or yet to come, and then left to rot. “I hope now that the veterans and their families finally get everything they deserve. It would be an awesome legacy for my mum. She fought so valiantly, and it broke her heart that there was no justice for her girls.”  Exposure risks Test veterans had higher death rates than the controls of cerebrovascular disease, respiratory and circulatory disease, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, and were more likely to die from accidents, violence, and intentional self-harm.In the first  years after the blasts, test survivors had a , per cent high risk of developing multiple myeloma, a  per cent higher risk of liver cancer, and were eight times more likely to get leukaemia. Even  years later, test veterans are still up to . times more likely to get leukaemia. The study also found evidence that may point to the psychological harm caused by the tests and subsequent official denials, with high rates of mouth cancer and cirrhosis among test veterans which, researchers said, “may indicate that alcohol use in certain subgroups of veterans was somewhat higher than in the general population”.It found increased risk of suicide for test veterans compared to the control group for every decade since the trials. “The highest rates of intentional self-harm were seen in the first  years of follow-up,” they said. Veterans later identied as being at most risk of radiation exposure had a  per cent higher risk of dying from suicide. aposUnacceptably radioactiveapos In , on the eve of a High Court case, the MoD admitted some servicemen were more likely to have been exposed to radiation. Researchers found these groups had a higher risk of stroke, which has also been noted in Japanese A-bomb survivors, and prostate cancer. On HMS Diana,  per cent of the  crew have died. Most were due to tumours, and  per cent of the crew had malignancies. More than a tenth had prostate cancer,  per cent had circulatory disease, and  per cent had ischaemic heart disease which has been linked to radiation. The captain later reported the ship was “unacceptably radioactive”, but the crew remained on board for another year. Operation Buffalo took place in Australia and  and included an “indoctrinee force” ordered to walk, crawl and run through fallout to see how much stayed on their unorms. Some were ordered to sit in tanks close to the blast to test the effect on men and machinery. The study found all of them had a radiation dose,  per cent were dead, more than a quarter died from cancer, and they had double the risk of dying from leukaemia and unspecied tumours.  RAF ground crew decontaminating planes which had flown sampling missions through the mushroom clouds were  times more likely than controls to die from leukaemia, and had raised rates of prostate cancer, and diseases of the heart and lungs. More than  per cent had a recorded radiation dose. Half of the air crew who flew the “snf” planes are dead, and  per cent had a recorded dose. They had double the controls’ rate of lung and blood cancer, and were almost four times more likely to die from unspecied growths. They also had seriously-raised risks of heart and lung disease, and deaths from accidents or violence. Men who took part in the minor trials, and Operation Dominic where UK servicemen witnessed multiple US bomb tests, had increased rates of almost every cancer and non-cancer disease that was studied. title: ordinary three bed home sale
story: Ordinary three-bed home on sale for £k - but its hiding filthy secret in every roomA three-bedroom property in London on Rightmove for £, has caused a stir after people noticed its got rubbish in each room - with one person even spotting a porn stashThe home is being offered for £, Image: Savills RightmoveByCourtney PochinSenior Audience WriterJosie OBrien:,  Feb |comments A house on the market in Hampstead, north west London, has got people online talking after they took a closer look at the Rightmove listing.Currently expected to sell for £,, the three-bedroom property is in need of some major TLC, as each room hides a rather filthy secret.Grim photos on the listing show that each room is incredibly run-down, with piles of rubbish and debris all over the place. Thereaposs a lot of discarded and broken furniture, black bin bags, clothes and clutter andthat werenapost enough, most of the walls are stained, the bathroom shows a toilet and sink covered in dirt and there are thick cobwebs everywhere.A Twitter user also spotted that in the virtual tour on Rightmove, a aposporn stashapos of magazines can be seen on a table on the upstairs landing. Get the news you want straight to your inbox. for a Mirror newsletter here.The piles of rubbish are so extreme throughout the home that they almost touch the ceiling in some rooms. It appears that the photographer even had to stand on a pile of bin bags and banished furniture to snap one of the three bedrooms. Old-style floral wallpaper can be seen around the house, which has peeled off in places, or is hanging from the walls. The propertyaposs green bin should be outside but instead stands guard in the downstairs hallway and things donapost improve in the front garden, which is overgrown with shrubbery and littered with a pile of bricks.  Those looking to get their hands dirty and undertake a rennovation project, would have a field day with this place which is described as being in need of complete modernisation on the Rigtmove ad. The property is going up for auction with Savills next Wednesdayand the full listing reads: A three storey three bedroom mid terrace house that benefits from a rear garden. In need of complete modernisation. The property is located in the sought after location of Primrose Hill, convenient to the fashionable restaurants and shops of the area.This comes after another seemingly ordinary-looking house for sale went viral.The property being sold in Norwich, Norfolk, captured peopleaposs attention after they spotted a rather bizarre feature in the terraced houseaposs master bedroom. The room featured a glass ensuite bathroom, which some said gave them aposloo anxietyapos as the toilet and shower are on full display to the rest of the room. After spotting the listing, a woman named Sarah tweeted: Today on Rightmove: Impress horry guests with a glass-walled khazi. One user replied: Iaposm hoping against hope that itaposs the sort of glass that magically goes frosted at the flick of a switch. Another wrote: I still wouldnapost trust it. Like those aposautomaticapos locks on train toilets - gives me loo anxiety. Someone  said: Errrrr itaposs a NO from me!!! While a dferent user added: Had one of those in a hotel room in Berlin. Was weird even as the only occupant. Brr.Do you have a property story to share  We pay for stories. news uk-news prince-harrys-offer-pay-security-"Prince Harrys security demands are inconsistent says ShipBySam Elliott-GibbsReporterTom Pilgrim:,  Feb |commentsPrince Harry has been told his offer to foot the bill for his own security in his ongoing legal challenge against the Home Office is irrelevant. The -year-old has applied for a judicial review of a decision not to allow him to personally pay for police protection for himself and his family when they are in the UKThe Duke of Sussex received insufficient information over a decision to change his tax-payer funded police protection when he is in the UK, the High Court has heard. Harry was told he would no longer be given the same degree of personal protective security when visiting from the US - despite offering to pay for it himself.He is taking on the Home Office because he wants to bring his children and we to visit from across the Atlantic. But Harry “does not feel safe” when visiting under the current security arrangements, the court was previously told. He is challenging the February  decision of the Executive Committee for the Protection of Royalty and Public Figures , which has delegated powers from the Home Secretary. Harry is arguing that his private protection team in the US does not have adequate jurisdiction abroad or access to UK intelligence information which is needed to keep his family safe.On Friday, the first hearing in the case continued at the Royal Courts of Justice in London, at which Harry was not present. The preliminary proceedings, which were largely held in private, related to an application by the Duke and the Home Office for some parts of court documents in the case to be kept private.  During an initial public part of Friday’s hearing, the judge, Mr Justice Swt, summarised the four grounds forming the basis of the duke’s legal challenge. He said these included an alleged “over rigid application of the policy” and a “failure” to take into account “relevant considerations”. The grounds also claim that conclusions reached were “unreasonable” and that “insufficient information” was provided in relation to the Ravec policy and “those involved in the Ravec decision”, the judge said. During the hearing, Shaheed Fatima QC, representing the duke, provided the judge with two letters “on the membership of Ravec”. She told court that “we’ve been asking about the membership”, later adding that this would relate to “the relevance of the claimant’s knowledge about who he was dealing with and in what capacity”.  Ms Fatima told the court that “we now know” that the Cabinet Office as an “entity” is a member of Ravec. She also told the judge that the duke previously had “correspondence” with Sir Mark Sedwill, a senior civil servant who served as Cabinet Secretary from April  to September . At the first part of the hearing held last week, the court heard that the duke considers that the UK “is and always will be, his home”. Ms Fatima told the court: “It goes without saying that he does want to come back to see family and friends and to continue to support the charities that are so close to his heart.” A legal representative for Harry previously said the duke wants to fund the security himself, rather than ask taxpayers to foot the bill. In written submissions, Robert Palmer QC, for the Home Office, argued that the duke’s offer to pay for his own security was “irrelevant” and that “personal protective security by the police is not available on a privately financed basis”. He said Ravec had attributed to the duke “a form of exceptional status” where he is considered for personal protective security by the police “with the precise arrangements being dependent on the reason for his presence in Great Britain and by reference to the s he carries out when present”. The barrister added: “A case-by-case approach rationally and appropriately allows Ravec to implement a responsive approach to reflect the applicable circumstances.” The Home Office’s written arguments also claim that Harry’s offer of funding was “notably not advanced to Ravec” at the time of the duke’s visit in June , or in any pre-action discussions. The duke briefly ed from Los Angeles last year for the July  unveiling of the Diana, Princess of Wales memorial statue and, the day before, on June , he met seriously ill children and young people at a WellChild garden party and afternoon tea in Kew Gardens, west London. It is understood the duke’s car was chased by photographers as he left. The duke and his we Meghan now live in the United States with their children Archie and Lilibet after quitting as senior working royals in early . Mr Justice Swt is expected to give his ruling on the initial court proceedings, part of which may be confidential, at a later date. title: queen shares favourite tv show
story: Queen shares favourite TV show - and she liked it so much she can even recite one-linersJournalist Phil Jones has claimed that The Queen once told him what her favourite programme was and even went on to recite several one-liners from a grandma characterThe Queen loved a British comedy show Image: Getty ImagesByCourtney PochinSenior Audience Writer:,  Feb |commentsMany people have speculated as to what type of television shows the royal family might watch in their own time, with some curiousthey love Netflixaposs The Crown, as much as we all do.But it turns out the Queenaposs favourite programme might surprise you. In a piece for The New Statesman, journalist Phil Jones claims that back in  the Queen told him all about her favourite show during a visit to Buckingham Palace.He claims heaposd kept their conversation a secret for  years as heaposd previously been told that journalists shouldnapost reveal their discussions with the monarch.However, now that heaposs leaving BBC Radio , he decided it was time to finally ulge what he had learned. The show in question  The Kumars at No. . He claims Her Majesty was such a big fan of the programme that she could even recite some of the one-liners from it. Jones wrote: In  I was invited to a mediaat Buckingham Palace. We chatted for ages, which I can tell you is rather surreal. My brain kept saying, aposBloody hell I’m talking to the Queen and I can’t think of a single thing to say!aposIn the end, I alighted on, aposWhat’s your favourite programme apos Straightaway, she said, apos The Kumars at No. apos and, even more astonishingly, proceeded to recite some of the one-liners from the grandma character, played by the brilliant Meera Syal.Jones added that The Queen also shared that she was a big fan of Terry Wogan during their conversation. However, he says this didnapost come as much of a surprise at the time, as he already knew she liked to listen to Radio . The Kumars at No.  was a British television show that ran from  to , spanning seven seasons. The programme starred Sanjeev Bhaskar as Sanjeev Kumar, an aspiring chat show host who had celebrity guest over to his house to talk to them. All would start to go wrong when Sanjeevaposs family started to interrupt the conversations, with the celebs ending up chatting more with his mother, father and grandmother. A six-episode revival series of the show was also made in  and aired on Sky, following orced Sanjeev and his family who now lived in a flat above their gt shop. .Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. news uk-news students-terrying-ordeal-waking-up-"Student relives horror night out when she was spikedByEmily CollisJoe Smith:,  Feb |comments A student has shared her terrying ordeal after she says her drink was spiked on a night out where she blacked out and woke up in hospital the next day with no memory. Tash Donald said a test then found drug traces similar to “roofies”, a date rape drug, in her system, after she reported the incident to police.The -year-old says she remembers starting to feel “strange” during a night out with friends at the Slug and Lettuce restaurant in Solihull, Birmingham on Friday, February . Psychology student Tash said her instincts kicked in after she started to feel unwell. She said she remembers nothing after heading into the girlaposs toilets at around .pm until she woke up the next day in hospital. Tash, from Olton in Solihull, then found out from family that she had asked her sister to pick her up, been repeatedly sick in the car and then fallen unconscious in her front garden, Birmingham Live reports. Can more be done to stop spiking  Have your say in the comment sectionBut it wasnapost until five days later, after reporting what happened to police, that Tash said a test discovered a drug similar to aposroofiesapos in her system. It was really terrying to find that out, said Tash, a student at the University of Birmingham.In some ways, I am lucky because my instincts kicked in to get out of there. If I hadnapost, I donapost know what could have happened. I just remember going into the toilets because I felt a bit strange and texting my sister saying I didnapost feel right. I think Iaposd had four or five drinks by that point which might sound a lot, but I do go out quite a lot and I knew how I felt wasnapost right for me. After that, I donapost remember anything. I only know what happened from what my family told me.  Apparently my sister rang me and said I didnapost sound right, she just thought I sounded very drunk at first. I donapost know how I got from the toilets to her car because none of my friends saw me but I obviously managed to get there somehow. While she was driving me home, she was having to hold me up because I completely lost control of my body. I was limp and nearly unconscious and was being sick over and over again. She rang my mum and said she thought Iaposd been spiked. By the time she got me home, I was unconscious. They rang an ambulance purely because they didnapost know what to do, they were really worried. The ambulance crew had to put me on the grass in the recovery position outside my house.  Tash was taken to hospital where she stayed under observation overnight. She woke up around .am the next morning feeling dazed and confused. I felt so confused, I couldnapost even remember my birthday when the nurse asked, said Tash. For a few days after, I just felt very tired. I was very zoned out, it was like brain fog. Suspecting she had been spiked, Tash reported the incident to police. She says the results of a drug test then came back positive for a sedative similar to Rohypnol, also known as aposroofiesapos.The part-time sales assistant has since taken to Instagram to share her story. Sheaposs hoping to raise awareness of the symptoms of spiking and has been overwhelmed by the response. Get the news you want straight to your inbox every day.to one of the Mirroraposs newsletters here I wanted to share my experience because I know a lot of people in my situation donapost report things, she said. From that post, I had five or six other girls message me to say they had been through a similar experience. The majority of them said they had never reported it as they assumed the police wouldnapost do anything, but from my experience the police have taken it really seriously. Theyaposre looking at CCTV and are doing an investigation. I would say Iaposm quite vigilant but there could have been a moment when I had my drink in my hand and wasnapost watching it, itaposs hard to say. I want to make other girls aware of the signs so they can look out for themselves and their friends. West Midlands Police confirmed it is investigating the incident and Slug and Lettuce told BirminghamLive it is assisting police with their enquiries.A police spokesperson said: Weaposre investigating a report of womanaposs drink being spiked on a night out in Solihull on Friday, February . She was taken to hospital after becoming unwell. A spokesperson for Slug and Lettuce Solihull added: “The safety and well-being of our guests is our main priority. news us-news woman-horried-after-discovering-hidden-"Shocked woman discovers hidden camera in her Airbnb bathroomByJoe Smith:,  Feb |comments A horried woman says she has found a secret camera watching her in the bathroom of her Airbnb apartment. Brittany Walsh posted a Tiktok video showing the surveillance device, which looks like a USB charger with a tiny pinhole lens in the front and an SD card slot in the back.That wasnapost the only spycam in the property however, the -year-old teacher and school psychologist also discovered a camera in the living room.Shocked Brittany posted a video of the device with the caption “Someone’s boutta catch a felony for invasive visual recording in our Airbnb bathroom.”She also recorded local police who came after she reported finding the bug, her vido shows two officers taking notes in the living room.What do you make of Brittanyaposs story  Have your say in the comment section “Looked like a plug…the camera part wasn’t obvious. We didn’t think anything of it for a while,” she wrote in the comments. Her video of the cameras found in her Airbnb room, which appears to be in the city of Austin, Texas has been viewed more than , times since Monday. She said her original video was deleted so she posted it again.“It’s a felony in Texas. And against Airbnb’s policy. It’s on their website of what they do and don’t allow in regard to cameras,” wrote Ms Walsh. She also said: “I assume the owners would be smart enough to hide it better. My best guess is their cleaning service put it there. Therecords locally to the SD card, you’d have to have the SD card itself to access the recordings.Get the news you want straight to your inbox every day.to one of the Mirroraposs newsletters here Has to be someone with repeated access.Airbnb said it is investigating, in a statement to DailyDot.Commenting on the video, one TikTok user suggested: “Put the micro SD card in a computer. The first video should be the person who originally plugged it in.” While others offered handy tips on how to spot hotels or holiday accomodation for hidden cameras. One wrote: “A big one is smoke alarms too. Most good cameras you would never find though. There are apps that can scan the Wi-Fi for devices that are cameras.” Another said: “Always turn all lights off and record with no flash on your phone everywhere in every room. If you see a flashing light it’s most likely a camera.” It said: Airbnb strictly prohibits aposhidden camerasapos as well as recording devices of any kind in private spaces such as bathrooms and bedrooms. We take this allegation extremely seriously and our dedicated safety team is thoroughly investigating. title: asda sparks backlash over models
story: Asda sparks backlash over models underwear photos as some say theyre a bad fitAsda have recently come under fire after sharing snaps of model Olivia Campbell via Instagram as some believe the underwear shes showcasing is a bad fit and looks uncomfortableSome feel the model has been given badly fitting underwear Image: @georgeatasda InstagramByJulia BanimAudience WriterRachel Pugh:,  Feb |comments As every woman knows, having a well-fitting and comfortable underwear set is just as important as choosing eye-catching colours or lacy details. After all, youaposre never going to feel like your most attractive selfyouaposre constantly aware of your knickers being too loose or too tight. In a recent picture uploaded to the Instagram account for Asdaaposs clothing range, George at Asda, plus-size model Olivia Campbell could be seen advertising the supermarket giantaposs pink and green lace sets. The non-padded lace bras are currently being sold in a two-pack online for £ and come in ious sizes. The model looked beautul in the snaps, however, as previously reported byManchester Evening News,a number of shoppers feel that the set is poorly fitted, and doesnapost do Olivia justice.  Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here. The post in question, captioned Gorgeous gorgeous girls, wear basics that make them feel amazing, features two pictures of Olivia, who can be seen beaming ear-to-ear. However, not all followers were quite so pleased with the post. One person wrote: It would be helpfulthey were properly fitting items. I’m all for curvy models and she’s gorgeous but those pieces do not fit her properly. A second commented: Listen, George... Iaposm that girlaposs size, sheaposs beautul and deserves more respect than to be made to wear panties that would slice your hoohar into two! I would not be comfortable in those and I would not feel sexy!Meanwhile, a third person remarked that, although it was brilliant that the supermarket is using plus size models, they should at least dress them in clothes that fit., adding that bra is such a bad fit and as for those knickers...cheese wire springs to mind. However, others took issue with the criticism, with another shopper remarking: The knickers fit... this is just what our fat bodies look like when we wear high leg knickers the same way everyone  does on social media. They added that the negativity in the comment section shows exactly why we need to normalise fat bodies by increasing representation everywhere. Olivia herself appeared quite happy with the undies, sharing the photos on her own Instagram account while declaring: I am feeling fabulous today! George at ASDA have released three empower poses. And I was the lucky babe that got to try on all their lovely lingerie and show you my favourite, which is the Flamingo pose. Now I feel like the ultimate boss babe. In a statement given to the Manchester Evening News, an ASDA spokesperson said: “The new George lingerie campaign highlights a positive message around both ersity and inclusion. We strongly believe that people from all walks of le should be represented equally and do not tolerate abusive comments directed towards any group of people including those featured on our social media channels.Do you have a story to share  We pay for stories. news weird-news dads-shock-glass-table-dfs-"Dining table shatters leaving family home covered in glassByKathleen SpeirsReporterGraeme Murray:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |commentsA dad was shocked after a glass table exploded after he had spent a whopping £ on the stylish item. The loud bang like an explosion happened after Malcolm Nicholson had settled down to watch a rugby international.He first though something had happened to his French doors due because of strong winds outside, the Daily Record reports.But he found his table was completely wrecked and glass covered his dining area.The -year-old firefighter and his son, , were sitting next to the explosion.Malcom and his we Joan, , contacted DFS immediately who told him they were looking into the matter. But the couple, from Skelmorlie, North Ayrshire, were furious when furniture firm DFS claimed the manufacturers were taking no responsibility for the incident.What do you make of the footage  Have your say in the comment section Malcolm, who shelled out more than £ on the table just  months ago, fears for other customers who bought the item and further damage which could be done. The dad-of-one said: I was watching Ireland v Wales in the Six Nations just along from our dining table, in the living room. All of a sudden we heard this loud bang, just like an explosion. When I realised it was the table I was stunned, there was glass everywhere. Video footage shows the extent of the damage. The entire glass top of the table is destroyed with the carpet blanketed with shards of glass.Get the news you want straight to your inbox every day.to one of the Mirroraposs newsletters here Shelves of the adjacent unit are covered in glass too, as well as the arm of a swivel chair shown in the images - which is where Malcomaposs son was seated. Malcolm added: I sat at the table earlier to do a bit of work on the laptop but that was it. Nothing was on it other than a note pad and a pen. We bought it in late  and have had no issues with it before. We keep it clean so would knowthere were any cracks. The item was part of a costly DFS haul for the Nicholsons who renovated their living and dining areas in  spending between £, and £, on a couch and some units. DFS manufacturers taking no responsibility for this is just staggering, Malcom said. To think how much money we spent on DFS just over a year ago and now weaposre left with nothing. This could have been so much worse, people could own this table and have babies or pets at home. My son was sat really close, glass could have gone in this eye. Weaposre really disappointed. A spokeswoman from DFS said: DFS are looking in to this.Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Consumer rightsDFS Furniture" data-immediate"data-immediate" to FREE email alerts with news to brighten your daySubscribeInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: ghost hunter left gasping air
story: Ghost hunter left gasping for air after being strangled by spirit in home of s iconIn scenes filmed for a new series, Celebrity Help! My House is Haunted, paranormal expert Barri Ghai was seemingly constrained while carrying out an investigation in the attic of s icon Toyah WillcoxThe moment a ghost hunter was strangled by evil spirit inside the haunted home of Toyah Wilcox Image: Discovery+ByLauren Beavis:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |comments A ghost hunter has claimed he was left gasping for air after a run-in with a ghoul in s icon Toyah Willcoxaposs home.The spirit seeker was reportedly strangled by an evil spirit in Toyahaposs property. In scenes filmed for a new series, Celebrity Help! My House is Haunted, paranormal expert Barri Ghai was seemingly constrained while carrying out an investigation in the attic. Ghai was joined by colleagues Ian Shaw and Jayne Harris, who had set up a special aposREMapos recording device at the home in Pershore, Worcestershire. The team were trying to speak with a ghost named George, which they believed to be a soldier who fought during the English civil war in the s.  Ghai could be seen clutching at his throat, before rushing out of the attic. He said: Something just grabbed my windpipe. F***ing scared the s**t out of me. I couldnapost get breath in, thataposs what scared me. I thought I was gonna die. I actually thought I was going to die. His colleague Harris then tried to speak with the spirit. Whoeveraposs doing that, can you step away please ” she said. “You do not have permission to do that. Step away from Barri.  Later in the episode, Ghai recounted the moment to Willcox. Straight away we got some kind of indication that there was a bit more of an aggressive male energy that was very dominant up there, he said. And then, I was sat there, I was talking, and all of a sudden my windpipe was constricted. I couldnapost breathe, I was actually really scared. The full hour-long episode is available to watch now on Discovery+ as part of a six-episode series. Willcox signed up for the show having experienced persistent paranormal activity ever since she moved to Worcestershire  years ago. title: girlfriend slammed forbidding partner cuddle
story: Girlfriend slammed for forbidding partner to cuddle his dog when shes aroundThe dog owner explained how he just wants to cuddle up on the sofa with his girlfriend and dog after a long week at work - but his partner has banned the dog from sitting with them" content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _Man-with-tattoo-embracing-his-dog.jpg" width"" "" The man has a two-year-old catahoulaImage: Getty ImagesByPaige FreshwaterContent Editor:,  Feb |commentsAfter a tough day at work, thereaposs nothing better than ing home to cuddle up with your dog.While most owners allow their dogs on their furniture, others believe dogs should stay on the floor.But one owner, who is used to cuddling up with his dog on the sofa, has vented his frustration at being denied this apossmall joy in leapos by his girlfriend.Turning to Reddit for advice, the man explained how he owns his own house and lived there with his two-year-old catahoula before his girlfriend moved in nine months ago.His girlfriend used to cuddle up with the rescue dog in bed and on the sofa before moving in - but changed her tune as soon as she got her own key to the house.to our TeamDogs newsletter for your weekly dose of dog news, pictures and stories.  He said: My does isnapost allowed even temporarily on the bed anymore, andmy girlfriend is on the sofa, the dog is forbidden to be on it. My girlfriend doesnapost like to be touched or cuddled with, eventhe dog is just chilling next to her and not bothering her, she has to be on the floor.Denying it has anything to do with dog hair, allergies or a traumatic previous experience, the man says he just doesnapost understand his girlfriendaposs sudden change in attitude towards his dog. My dog is well-behaved and the best pal I could ask for, he said. She is toilet trained, never destroys things and loves to sleep in her crate without issue. I was raised around four or five dogs at a time just never had my own in my own house until now. She is the first dog who is actually mine.  Having dreamt about spending a lazy Saturday afternoon watching a movie with his girlfriend and dog on the sofa, the man has questioned how he can get his partner to warm up to the idea. He added: Itaposs a simple harmless joy that is really selfishly important to me. They are my family and it is the best feeling in the world to me. However, my girlfriend wonapost allow this. Ever. Never ever. Forbidden. The man has tried to explain to his girlfriend how he feels about this issue - but says their chats soon turns into a heated argument. If the dog is cuddling with me on the couch watching a show on TV, my girlfriend leaves the room or it becomes an argument and I lose my s*** because I feel like this is such a trivial pathetic issue, he said.The dog does not get crazy, and will relaxwe tell her not to climb as all dogs might try at first - but she causes no harm and just chills. She wants to be part of the family. My girlfriend says aposShe can be part of it on the floorapos. She has no rationale or credible argument for why. She denies jealousy but I think itaposs a bit jealous and selfish on her behalf knowing full well itaposs a simple request of mine and that Iaposve compromised with never having the dog ever on the bed again. Why canapost the dog just cuddle with us one in a while on a lazy day watching a movie on the sofa. Making matter worse, the man explained how his girlfriend has worked as a dog bather for years, claiming to love spending time with dogs. She buys his dog toys and plays with her on the floor - but hasnapost cuddled her from the day she moved in.  He added: She has also never walked the dog a single time, even when I asked because I would have been late to work or was sick and really could have used her help. No - she refuses. She has a snake which is not my jam at all, I dislike reptiles, but itaposs part of her and I acknowledge that and whatever positives it brings her I accept because it makes her happy and thataposs what matters to me. I respect her and what she likes, although I am sometimes hesitant, but iaposm there with open arms. Not a deal at all. While most users agreed that his girlfriend is being unreasonable about not allowing the dog on the sofa, especially when he owns the house and furniture inside, others spoke about the red flags he highlighted in his relationship. One user said: Someone who does a complete turn around after getting what they want - which was to move in - is a major red flag. She manipulated you into letting her move in and now she’s being abusive to your dog. Itaposs time for a new girlfriend. While another user added: I have the feeling the issue isn’t so much with the dog as it is other aspects of the relationship and your dog is just acting as a catalyst here. If your partner is not open to conversation about it, you’re likely better off giving up the relationship altogether or having a mediator like a counsellor help you two explore why you two cannot compromise. Do you have a dog story to sell  Email paige.freshwater@reachplc. title: iphone lost 10 years pulled
story: iPhone lost for  YEARS is pulled from toilet after husband hears odd noiseThe iPhone in question was barely even cracked despite  years in the toilet when they fished it out after hearing a banging sound from their looThe husband was surprised by what he pulled out of the loo Image: FacebookBySophie FosterLestyle  Travel ReporterMichele Theil:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |commentsA man who tried to unblock his toilet after hearing a weird noise managed to find an item that his we lost ten years ago. Becki Beckmannaposs husband started hearing a banging sound when they flushed the toilet and so he decided to plunge it.He was surprised to find the iPhone that Becki lost ten years ago, news.au reported. Writing on Facebook, Becki said the couple initially blamed the noise on the toilet being old or the house construction being terrible.But, her husband was fed up and sought to plunge the f**k out of it. After a while, she said he came running outside to say that she wouldnapost believe what he found in our toilet.What do you make of the find  Have your say in the comment section The phone was lodged deep in the toiletaposs pipes, and photos posted by Becki showed that the back casing was lting, exposing the tech inside. Becki lost her iPhone  around Halloween in , and after searching for a while, she gave up and bought a new phone. She said she was super confused when it went missing as she hadnapost left the house that day nor had she been drinking, but she hasnapost thought about it since. Becki said:I replaced [the phone], moved on. whatever. It was mysterious but it was gone. This was so, so far from what I was expecting.  Get the news you want straight to your inbox every day.to one of the Mirroraposs newsletters here The post went viral, with hundreds of people commenting their thoughts on toilet maintenance. One person said: Thereaposs no way it was stuck in your toilet for  years and never caused an issue until it started making a sound. A second person wrote: How have yaposall not had any clogging  My townhouse get son baby wipe in its pipe and I get all the neighbours sh*t in my laundry room. How come my glass screen breaks when I even so much as look at it but you can literally sh*t on yours for years and itaposs perfect  another joked. Though the iPhone looked almost pristine, it is likely that ten years of toilet waterhas rendered it inoperable. title: i spent 150 menu michelin
story: I spent £ on the menu at a Michelin star restaurant - the food made me cryKirsty Bosley spent an eyewatering £ on a meal for one at a Michelin star restaurant to seethe pricey food was worth it - and the menu reduced her to tearsKirsty Bosley spent £ on her fine dining experience Image: Kirsty BosleyByZahna EklundAudience writerKirsty Bosley:,  Feb |comments Have you ever wondered what a fine dining experience is really like  We may have seen people indulging their expensive tastes in films, but for many of us, spending more than £ on a meal for one person is a cost reserved only for the most special of occasions - usually milestone birthdays that weaposve spent the year beforehand saving up for. But is splashing the cash on a pricey meal actually worth it  Birmingham Live reporter Kirsty Bosley headed down to Adamaposs, a Michelin star restaurant in Birmingham, to find out.In total, Kirsty spent £ on the experience and for her money, she was treated to a tasting menu that included everything on the restaurantaposs menu. Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here. The restaurant Kirsty noted she was blown away by the service she received as soon as she walked through the doors - with staff on hand to take her coat, and see her to her table. The reporter was also impressed by the decision to remove the extra chair from her table-for-one, as she said it eliminated the feeling of being lonely that an empty chair can sometimes bring when dining by yourself. Whataposs more, Adamaposs remembered Kirstyaposs request to be shown the vegetarian menu when she booked her table and stuck to it throughout the evening so the reporter didnapost have to think about her dietary requirements.  According to Kirsty, Adamaposs offers three courses for £, five for £, or the whole menu for £ - which is called the tasting menu. The reporter chose to try a little bit of everything and ordered herself a £ peach Bellini on top to wash it all down. The food Kirsty was treated to seven dishes in total, including four starters, the main course and two puddings - although the reporter admitted it was hard to keep track of which dishes she was getting. Although the dishes she received were small, Kirsty noted that the flavour of every morsel was better than she had expected, and left her wanting more every time.  First, the woman received a pretty red beetroot meringue with some kind of little rice cracker thing on top, as well as two pieces of cucumber that the lady who brought it tipped green gazpacho over. Kirsty said she loved both dishes and had initially assumed they were part of her starters until she was informed they were actually just other little dishes to try which the restaurant did not charge more for. When the reporteraposs starters did arrive, they came with a stack of four knives, four forks and four spoons - leaving Kirsty to believe she was going to be truly out of her depth. But the woman was instead overcome with emotion when she tried her first starter consisting of cucumber, lime, and wasabi, as she said: My eyes watered, my mouth watered. It was a ridiculous explosion of flavours that sent my senses into overdrive. I could have kissed the chefsuch a thing wouldnapost get me barred for le.  Kirsty even told the waitress she had enjoyed her starter so much she wanted to lick the plate, and thought her taste experience couldnapost get any better - until the second starter arrived. The reporter was treated to white asparagus with edible flowers followed by leek parcels and Jerusalem artichoke, and she explained that by the end of the third starter a tear had actually escaped and made its way happily down my nose. Kirstyaposs main course, wild mushrooms, was described as thrilling and the two desserts were to die for. The woman said she even got little extra treats when she was paying her bill, including a little bottle of salted caramel and miso syrup for her afternoon coffee and a aposgooey salted caramel chocolateapos to take away. Final thoughts In total, Kirsty spent £. on her Michelin star food journey - and while the price tag was definitely more than your standard trip to Nandos, she said she would save up to do it again in a heartbeat. Summing up her experience, she wrote: While Iaposd got a few photos of my dishes, and one of me enjoying one, I was aware that nothing could possibly capture that experience. The way that all of my senses had been aroused, it just felt like alchemy. Suddenly, they were not tiny little plates of food for big prices. They were experiences, knowledge and expertise, presented in such a way that I could have flownI wasnapost anchored to the restaurant floor by a crisp table topped with stacks of cutlery. Kirsty, who describes herself as common as muck, said the £ price tag was easily worth it for the experience she had and insisted sheaposd be going back to chase that feeling again.Do you have a story to sell  Get in touch with us at yourmirror@trinitymirror .Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON FoodRestaurants" data-immediate"data-immediate"Serve the food you really want to eat by signing up for our tips and recipes and never be bored by your cooking againSign UpInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you.
