title: mum fumes school letting child
story: Mum fumes at school for letting child, , watch Newsround as it left her upsetThe mum is furious at her daughters school after they allowed her to watch an episode of Newsround about Russias invasion of Ukraine which left her very upsetThe mum is worried about what her daughter is being exposed to at schoolImage: Getty ImagesByZahna EklundAudience writer:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |comments Getting children to keep up with current affairs can be invaluable for their development as they grow up to be well-informed young people who are engaged with the world around them.But thereaposs a fine balance that needs to be struck when it comes to deciding what to show them, as many parts of the news can be unsettling for adults to watch, let alone kids.One mum on Mumsnet has been left outraged by teachers at her eight-year-old daughteraposs school after they allowed her class to watch an episode of Newsround, BBC aposs news programme for children, that covered Russiaaposs invasion of Ukraine. The scenes shown on the news over recent days have been overwhelming for many of us, and after the womanaposs daughter came home very upset and worried about what might happen, she took to Mumsnet to claim it was inappropriate of the school to tell young children about the conflict.Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here. In her post, she said: I think that it is important for children to know what is happening in the world - to an extent.My -year-old daughter came home today very upset and worried as she had seen on Newsround - which is shown at her school - that Russia has invaded Ukraine. She has asked me several timeswe were going to get aposhitapos. I have tried to reassure her that it wonapost happenand not to worry. She then asked me to swear on her le that we wonapost be affected by it. I said I couldnapost swear on her le but not to worry, it wonapost happen.She is very anxious and I just donapost think something so serious should have been shown to -year-old children. I feel so sorry for them, theyaposve had Covid and now this! Commenters on the forum were quick to remind the mum that Newsround is specically designed for children between the ages of six and , and said the language that was used will have been appropriate for her daughteraposs age group. And others also noted that although the young girlaposs fear is understandable, itaposs also important for her to learn about world news in a well-informed and appropriately explained way. One person said: Newsround is designed for children of her age though, isn’t it  Maybe a heads up from the school would be good so parents are ready to answer questions, but children are going to overhear adults talking about it so it’s better that it’s explained properly. While another added: My eight-year-old has seen Newsround at school. In my opinion, it’s better they learn about these types of things in a well informed and appropriately explained way that enables discussion and the chance to allay fear, than overhearing snippets of adult conversation and scaring yourself half to death imagining the rest. The mum isnapost the only one to have raised concerns about schools showing Newsround episodes to students though, as we previously covered the story of another mum who said she didnapost want her kids, aged eight and , to watch the programme because she deemed it too alarming. She wrote: “Every class at my children’s school seems to watch Newsround on a daily basis. “We deliberately avoid watching the news with them around, because so much of it is alarming for people who havenapost yet got adult perspective on things. “News TV is deliberately curated to make it as arresting and attention-grabbing as possible, and obviously concentrates more on the bad stuff than anything . Canapost they just have a childhood before theyaposre confronted with the dark sides of human nature ”Do you have a story to sell  Get in touch with us at yourmirror@trinitymirror .Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON NewsroundBBCEducationParenting" data-immediate"data-immediate" to FREE email alerts with news to brighten your daySubscribeInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: mum perplexed pal bans birthday
story: Mum perplexed as pal bans her from birthday party - after planning a trip awayThe mum said she planned a holiday for herself and her best friend to celebrate her pals birthday and in , the friend chose not to invite her to her partyThe mum has been banned from her friends birthday partyImage: Getty Images Image SourceByZahna EklundAudience writer:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |comments A mum has been left baffled after her best friend decided to ban her from attending her birthday party - even though sheaposd planned an entire holiday for the two of them to celebrate the occasion. The woman took to Mumsnet to vent her frustration after her friend told her she hadnapost received an invite to her upcoming th birthday party because they were already going away together, and she didnapost want her to attend both celebrations.Sharing her post anonymously, the woman claimed the party is taking place just  minutes away from her house and said other mutual friends of theirs are invited - but she wonapost be going as the birthday girl has banned her. Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here. Explaining the situation, she said: Iaposve been friends with this woman for years and we had booked a trip away together in . It got moved from  to  due to Covid and has landed on the week of her th. Sheaposs single and childfree so I checked she was happy with the date change and she said aposas long as you promise to make a proper fuss of me!apos. We are away for  days and her birthday is in the middle of the trip. I found out through a mutual friend that she has booked a party for two days after we come back. Itaposs a pub so sheaposs not paying per head and itaposs about  minutes from my house. I asked her why I wasnapost invited and she said itaposs because weaposre going away that week. We do have mutual friends that have been invited. Is it unreasonable to be a bit hurt annoyed by this  Iaposm also now not sure what to do for her actual birthday.The mum insisted sheaposs friends with people who have been invited to the party and has no idea why she wouldnapost be invited herself - but thinks it could be because she would have technically already celebrated her birthday. She added in follow-up posts: I donapost have beef with anyone at the party and one person is more my friend than hers. I think the reasoning was more that we would have already celebrated her birthday. Comments on the Mumsnet post were equally baffled by the friendaposs actions, as no one could work out why the mum wouldnapost be invited. Might make the last couple of days of your holiday a bit awkward, but who needs friends like that  One person said: Thataposs a bit mean, odd and petty. If I wanted to be mean, odd and petty back Iaposd completely ignore her birthday on the day. As another added: I wouldnapost make a fuss on her actual birthday. Maybe get her a card. If you arenapost a good enough friend to be invited to her birthday party then you donapost need to buy her a present.Do you have a story to sell  Get in touch with us at yourmirror@trinitymirror .Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Birthday partyUmm what " data-immediate"data-immediate" to FREE email alerts with news to brighten your daySubscribeInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: my mum refuses walk dog
story: My mum refuses to walk my dog - she says his name is too embarrassingThe owner recently adopted a labrador puppy with his girlfriend and gave the dog a funny name to suit his own sense of humour - but his mum refuses to shout it in publicHis dogs unique name brings him joy Image: Getty Images iStockphotoByPaige FreshwaterContent Editor:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |commentsWhen choosing a dogaposs name, some owners spend hours mulling over unique names, while others simply opt for tried and tested classics.While youaposll always hear a Rufus or Fido being called in the park, itaposs less common to spot a dog with a name that makes you do a double-take.One owner has shared how their dogaposs unique name has been causing problems within their family after their mum refused to walk their dog because of it.Seeking reassurance on Reddit, the owner explained how he wanted to name his dog something funny because it would create more joy in his day-to-day le. to our TeamDogs newsletter for your weekly dose of dog news, pictures and stories. He said: So I personally find this hilarious but my mother does not. I recently got a lab puppy and I named him Woof.Some of my friends like it, others think it is silly, while my mother hates it. Unable to understand why her son would name his dog Woof, the mum refuses to walk his dog in public. He says his mum cannot fathom calling Woofaposs name in a park as it would fill her with too much embarrassment to shout within earshot of others. I guess thataposs just my own sense of humour because I laugh when I call my dogaposs name out loud at a dog park, he added.  Although he has told his mum she doesnapost have to walk his dogshe doesnapost want to, the son says he wouldnapost be able to contain his laughterhe heard her shouting: Woof! Come here! No, Woof, Woof. No get down Woof! Woof!apos. He added: Itaposs not like I need her to walk him as my girlfriend and I have plenty of time to do that ourselves - but my mother thinks iaposm a bit of an a***h*** for the name still. While most users agreed it is a hilarious name for a dog, others sought inspiration from it and came up with their own future dog names. One user said:I want to name a dog Everyone so I can yell aposEveryone, get I insideapos and aposEveryone stop snfing my a***!apos This seems fine and fun. Having already given their dog a funny name, one user said: We have a brown dog named Poo because heaposs brown - and we are still laughing  years later at aposOh, look! Thereaposs Poo on the rugapos, aposThereaposs Poo in the car,apos aposThereaposs Poo on the bedapos. My dad has gotten a lot of mileage out of this. Another said: My parents have a lovely all-white boxer that they let my little brother name when he was quite young, he named him Boo like a ghost. I felt like an idiot every time I would be out walking him and had to tell somebody his name and they gave me pretty weird looks. I do love that dog, but I never really got past his name. Does your dog have an unusual name  Email paige.freshwater@reachplc. title: my yorkshire terrier stupid hes
story: My Yorkshire terrier is so stupid hes costing me a fortune in vet billsThe mans dog will not stop weeing on ant hills, despite being highly allergic to ants, and its starting to cost him a lot of money at the vets almost every monthHes never had a dog so dumb Image: Getty Images iStockphotoByPaige FreshwaterContent Editor:,  Feb |commentsWatching a dog trip over their own feet and flop onto the floor is adorable, providing they havenapost hurt themselves.But a clumsy dog can cost its owner a fortune in vet bills. One owner knows this all too well after venting his frustration about his Yorkshire terrier who is always at the vets and leaving him out of pocket almost every month.Speaking about his accident-prone pooch on Reddit, the man explained how he adopted a -year-old dog in June last year - and has been back and forth to the vets ever since.He said: I love him but he’s the stupidest dog to ever exist. I’ve never had a dog this dumb.to our TeamDogs newsletter for your weekly dose of dog news, pictures and stories.  His dog has a aposfascination for peeing in peculiar places, such as inside spiky bushes or on other creatures. He loves peeing in ant hills but is very allergic to ants, he said. I often have to bring him into the vet because he peed in an anthill and the ants didn’t like it.Just today he climbed into a bush to pee, and I had to pull splinters out of his testicles. Unable to teach him a single command, not even apossitapos, the man is at a loss with his dog, saying Iaposm just worried for his safety at this point. He added: He also constantly jumps off of things he shouldn’t. He weighs five pounds and sprains his legs a lot. I turn away for five seconds and he’s trying to hurt himself in some dumb way. He also loves to eat plastic and I have had to shove my fingers down his throat to stop him from choking more times than I can count. The man believes his dogaposs lack of intelligence stems from being abused by his previous owner - and from being locked away from the world around him. He has a few broken bones that healed, and I know he was locked in a tiny kennel for five years straight before I got him, he said. They gave him food and water, and cleaned the kennel once a month, but they never took him to a groomer or talked to him.So I’m trying my best, but he may just be happy to be out, so he’s exploring and doing everything he loves. Before asking for advice, the man explained how he has previously worked with a professional trainer and has been trying out their tips on his dumb dog - but it all just goes over the dogaposs head. He said: He’s on a two-foot leash when we’re out. He physically can’t pull away from our feet but he still finds ant hills.We also have stairs to prevent him jumping off stuff but he still jumps. While most users laughed at his clumsy dog, others tried to share a word of advice with the struggling owner.One user said: Not going to lie, I laughed at the mental image of your dog peeing on an anthill.Your dog, while dumb, sounds adorable!But yes, it is a safety issue. My advice would be to work with a dog trainer on teaching your dog commands like aposcome,apos apossit and aposleave itapos - these are important for safety and setting boundaries . Another user added: I am so sorry you are having such a hard time, but your writing is so funny that I couldnapost help chuckle at the thought of you pulling splinters out of his testicles. Have you tried positive reinforcement, wherehe pees on a clear grass patch as opposed to somewhere he shouldn’t, you reward him Or a really short leash till he is done peeing and then more room for him to walk after that  Ramps and steps should help with the jumping too. title: teen praised exposing mum after
story: Teen praised for exposing mum after she allowed her sister to steal from herA teenager has been forced to turn to her aunt after her own sister stole her birthday money and her mum didnt have the heart to tell her she couldnt keep the cashThe teen told her aunt what her sister and mum had been up to Image: Getty Images iStockphotoByEmma RosemurgeyAudience Writer:,  Feb |comments A teen is being praised after revealing sheaposd exposed her older sister for stealing from her - and her mum for allowing her to do it.The -year-old says her sister, , constantly steals from her and messes up her things, but when sheaposs tried talking to their parents about it, they simply shrug it off and say sisters do things like that.Three weeks ago, I received money from my aunt and friend for my birthday. I was excited because Iaposve wanted AirPods for a while now and I finally had enough money to get them. I kept the money in a box and put it in my drawer, the teen wrote on Redditaposs AITA forum.About a week ago, I wanted to go to the gas station so I went to get the money but when I checked it wasn’t there. I went and asked my mumshe’d seen it to which she replied yes. She told me that my sister went snooping in my room and wanted the money and mum aposdidnapost have the heart to say no.apos So she let her take it.  For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here. I went to my sisteraposs room and demanded she gives me my money back. She told me that she already spent it and that I aposshould’ve hidden it betterI didnapost want it stolen.apos I was livid. I stormed to my room and stayed there for the rest of the day, she continued. A couple of days ago, the teen was out shopping with her aunt, when her aunt askedsheaposd managed to her hands on the AirPods sheaposd been wanting. So, she told her aunt about S stealing the money and she was furious. My aunt called my mum to berate her and told me I could stay the night with her. When I got home to pack my things, mum was furious and threw money at me askingI was aposhappy nowapos that I made S feel bad. I ignored her, grabbed my things, and left, she continued. While at my auntaposs place I received many nasty texts from family members saying I was in the wrong. My dad told me that he didn’t agree with what my mum and S did, but I didnapost have to expose them to my aunt. The teen then turned to Reddit to question whether sheaposd done the right thing as sheaposd been left feeling extremely guilty over whataposd happened. Your sister is a thief and both of your parents are enablers. Iaposm glad you have an adult who is treating you well, one Reddit user wrote, while another added: Good for you for exposing them for the thieves they are. A third added: Your mum and your sister are the a**holes, and your father is just as bad. Good on your aunt for offering you a place to stay. If you can stay there permanently, all the better.Do you have a story to share  We want to hear all about it. news weird-news woman-goes-viral-after-being-"TikTok user is hilariously held hostage by a swanByKirsty FeerickJournalistGraeme Murray:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |comments A woman has gone viral after being aposheld hostageapos by a stalker swan which would not leave her alone. Siobhán, a mum-of-two, filmed the large bird trying to come into her home and even trying to prevent her car from moving as as she tried to leave her driveway. The angry bird prevented her from leaving her home and she shared a clip of its antics on TikTok.The short piece of footage attracted more than , views since she posted it with the video caption, ‘My le is a jokeapos.The Daily Record reports that she said to the bird: What’s your problem big man , and Are you going to just stand at the door asthat’s normal . What do you make of Siobhánaposs story  Have your say in the comment section It blocks her car on the road later in the clip and Siobhan is heard saying excuse me pal, this is a joke. Iaposm literally being held hostage by a swan. The bird, a protected species, lives directly across the street from Siobhán at a local pond but has recently become a determined visitor at her house. It appears in the street and then on her doorstep and tries to get into her house which sparks shrieks and cries of wow at how tame it had become. The feathered friend appeared to follow Siobhán wherever she was headed and was a constant presence as she tried to go about her everyday business.It appears the fitness instructor eventually grew fond of the animal as she posted later videos of her going to the supermarket to buy it some food. But when she presented a bowl of cabbage, lettuce, and cucumber, the swan hissed at her and tipped it over. Siobhánaposs videos have garnered hundreds of likes and comments with Tiktok users in stitches over the bizarre love-hate friendship.  Get the news you want straight to your inbox every day.to one of the Mirroraposs newsletters here One person said: ”The swan is showing TV licence man behaviour.” People observed the close relationship between the two and suggested the feathered friend adored her. A second person said: “That swan loves you!” Further posters responded and suggested the swan was Scottish and had anger problems which needed to be reined in. Someone added: “It’s got anger issues, must be a Scottish swan!” But other posters were fascinated by the big birdaposs behaviour and loved watching what it got up to. A fourth person, meanwhile, said: “I am now invested in this swan. You can follow more of Siobhán’s content on her Tiktok account @siobhan.scot. news weird-news woman-transforms--year-old-"Woman transforms -year-old house with just £, budgetByJulia BanimAudience WriterAmy Walters:,  Feb |comments A keen DIY-er has inspired interior design fans all over the world after documenting the extraordinary transformation of her -year-old house.The woman, known only as Tay, bought the charming property back in  and set about putting her own unique stamp on it, adding quirky details such as cow print furniture, disco balls, and D aposgrassapos walls.The -year-old from San Francisco has completely transformed the period home to fit with her own fun style, complete with colourful prints, pigmented colours, and eclectic objects, all for a relatively snippy budget of £,. She has since shared her revamping progress via TikTok, with her thrty approach and interesting taste in decor attracting , admiring followers.  Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here.In one particular post, which has clocked up . million views and . million likes, Tay shows just how much hard work has gone into her one-of-a-kind home renovation project. Showing her followers her hand-painted ceiling mural in the hallway, Tay then moves into the bedroom, where sheaposs created a D grass-like wall The creative homeowner can then be seen painting eye-catching green loops on the wall beside her staircase and hanging shimmering disco balls in her living room area. Viewers are also treated to glimpses of her cow-print chairs and stunning hand-painted wall designs.  Tay, who learned DIY skills through YouTube tutorials as well as through good old-fashioned trial and error, hasnapost opted for any particular theme, and regards the space as a reflection of her active imagination, tying in aspects of things that she finds to be fun. She said: [My favourite room] is the living room – it’s a reminder of all the work I’ve done on the house. Everywhere you look is a massive project I did completely on my own and it’s a visible output of all my work. I painted a mural on the ceiling, made a custom cow print giant mirror, wallpapered for the first time, and made a velvet headboard behind my couch. Tay has had help from her boyfriend, Andrew, , with the couple having recently moved in together. Given that Andrew is an industrial designer, his professional knowledge has proven greatly useful throughout the process, and heaposs become Tayaposs go-to person for DIY questions.  According to Tay, the ambitious undertaking has proven beneficial for her mental health, helping her deal with a post-traumatic stress disorderwhich had left her crying constantly and scared for my health. Tay said: I had just bought my place, so I felt trapped and like I couldn’t get out. I decided I was going to completely change the house and all the white walls so that it was the happiest and safest environment I could be in. I spent all my free time working on projects around the house and this really motivated me to get a lot done in a quick amount of time. love problem solving and figuring out how to do things on my own. She added: I think I’ve done everything to the best of my ability and I can’t ask for anything more. I’ve always loved the high curved ceilings, crown mouldings, and the original hardware on all the doors. It has amazing historic charm and accents still in the house. Tay, who began her renovation by purchasing five gallons of paint to create a mural without realising sheaposd bought too much, advised others keen to pursue similar endeavors to “start with the paint and see where it takes you.Do you have an interior design story to share  We pay for stories. title: china begins turn putin calls
story: China begins to turn on Putin as it calls for Russia to negotiate with UkrainePresident Xi Jinping is said to have told Vladimir Putin in a phone call that China supports under siege Ukraine and wants Russia to resolve the issue through negotiationsChinese President Xi Jinping is said to have told his Russian counterpart he supports negotiation Image: Alexei Druzhinin TASSByAntony ThrowerNews Reporter:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |commentsChina ’s president has seemingly denounced Vladimir Putin’s invasion of Ukraine, telling his Russian counterpart he supports the crisis being resolved through talks.The Far East superpower is said to be keeping close watch on the Kremlin’s brutal and deadly invasion of its southern neighbour. Ukraine confirmed earlier today that  civilians and military personnel had been killed in the country during the first day of the assault, with more than  wounded in the fighting. Far from the frontlines, Putin took a call from China’s President Xi Jinping, Aljazeera reports. According to state broadcaster CCTV, XI said: “[The] “situation in eastern Ukraine has undergone rapid changes … [and] China supports Russia and Ukraine to resolve the issue through negotiation. He added Putin should “abandon the Cold War mentality, attach importance to and respect the reasonable security concerns of all countries, and form a balanced, effective and sustainable European security mechanism through negotiations”. The unprovoked invasion of neighbouring Ukraine by Russian forces on the command of President Vladimir Putin has sparked bloodshed and chaos. With Putinaposs troops shelling cities across Ukraine and the nationaposs army vowing to fight to the death to defend their land, observers fear the death toll will be enormous.So far, it has been confirmed by President of Ukraine Volodymyr Zelensky that  civilians and military personnel were killed in the country on the first day of the Russian invasion. In an address to his people, Mr Zelensky revealed a further  had been wounded in the fighting. The death toll is set to rise as, on the night of February , Ukraine’s deputy defence minister Hanna Maliar claimed nearly , Russian servicemen had died during the first two days of the deep invasion She wrote in a Facebook post that the troops of the invading country have suffered the following lossesas of pm Friday, before going on to list up to  tanks  armoured combat vehicles of ious types  aircraft seven helicopters and , special staff she claims were among the losses suffered by Russia. Meanwhile, the official Twitter page of the Ministry of Defense of Ukraine claimed in a tweet that today the number of losses from the occupying forces of the Russian Federation is more than  thousand. These claims have not yet been independently veried. According to the Chinese media readout, Putin replied saying: “The United States and NATO have long ignored Russia’s reasonable security concerns, repeatedly reneged on their commitments, and continued to advance military deployment eastward, challenging Russia’s strategic bottom line.“Russia is willing toconduct high-level negotiationswith Ukraine.”China has refused to call its ally’s actions an invasion or criticise Putin’s actions which have dragged the world to the brink of war. This evening the nation abstained voting in the United Nations Security Council draft resolution that condemned Russia for invading Ukraine.  Other world leaders have heavily criticised Russiaaposs invasion, amid warnings of heavy sanctions on the Kremlin. Putin’s troops are marching on Kyiv with brave Ukrainian troops positioned on the streets to block Russian invaders. Civilians have been urged to target invaders using petrol bombs, with Ukrainian men aged between  and  barred from leaving the country and told to take up arms.  This morning Ukrainian deputy defence minister Anna Maliar said enemy troops had driven two Ukrainian army trucks into Kyiv, followed by a convoy of military trucks.In aFacebookpost she said the Russians were “moving at speed to the centre of Kiev, adding: “They will surely be destroyed.”Boris Johnson earlier condemned Russia for unleashing a “tidal wave of violence” onUkraine , warningPutinwould achieve “pariah status”. He told MPs: “We will continue on a remorseless mission to squeezeRussiafrom the global economy piece by piece, day by day, week by week.”Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Xi JinpingVladimir PutinPoliticsRussia Ukraine war" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: feeling huge explosions russia invaded
story: Feeling huge explosions as Russia invaded Ukraine was surreal and terryingMirror reporter Andy Lines is in Kyiv, Ukraine. He counted  explosions as Russia targeted military establishments on the citys outskirts before am this morning after Vladimir Putin ordered an invasionAn image taken from the Ukrainian Presidents office after an explosionopinionByAndy Lines in Kyiv:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |comments As I stood in the darkness on a hotel roof in Kyiv at am, the sky was suddenly lit up by a massive, ominous orange glow and I heard and felt a booming explosion.The blast – the sound of a Russian missile hitting its target – was too close for comfort. Before am I counted  explosions as Russia targeted military establishments on the city’s outskirts. It seemed scarcely believable that a full scale invasion could take place in Europe in .As Russia sent its forces into Ukraine, it is feared that more than  people, including  soldiers and one child, have been killed.Tens of thousands of terried families have fled the capital.  When the bombardment started this morning I was standing on a pavement on a deserted road in central Kyiv with an Italian TV reporter who I had never met before. We had been woken minutes earlier by a faint rumbling noise in the distance and went out to investigate. At first I couldn’t believe the bombing could be so close to Kyiv. As I nervously climbed the stairs up to the roof of the hotel the bangs became louder. This was when I felt the huge explosion and realised I was witnessing a powerful sustained attack. Dawn broke an hour or so later and screeching air sirens started to wail – overpowering the gentle chimes of church bells marking the time.  The sirens sent terried pedestrians running into the church for safety. Some people were driving to work. Two women walked their dogs in the church square, asunaware of Vladimir Putin’s attack. It was surreal. But within hours the enormity of the assault had been fully realised across the city. As two fighter jets flew over the capital, there were long queues at cashpoints. Postman Peter Aliyev, , said: “I wanted to get some money out when I could. I have a young family and we will head out of Kyiv this morning to get to the countryside to stay with relatives.” A young woman in tears joined the queue. The city was living on its nerves as it awaited the next attack.  It remained unclear last night how close Russian tanks are to the capital. Airborne troops have reached a military airport just  miles away. And at least six helicopters were seen flying over Hostomel, a commuter town on the outskirts of Kyiv. Apartment complexes in some cities were hit by missiles. One woman, a teacher, in Chuhuiv had blood pouring from a head wound. The deep metro system in Kyiv at least gave families some safety. Hundreds of children and dozens of pet cats and dogs were on the s of one station.  A student Andriy, , said: “We have always regarded Russia as our big brother. I didn’t expect this to happen. And this is just the start – we have no idea what will happen next. Ukraine will never be the same after this.” People had packed up what they could and fled in their cars – hoping their homes and possessions will still be there when andthey . On a motorway heading out of Kyiv there was a traffic jam stretching miles. Families got out and chatted nervously until the sirens went off again and they jumped back into their cars.  Some people walked down the side of the motorway wheeling suitcases and thumbing for a lt. At the main bus station, coaches were packed to the rafters as they drove off. Many shops were shut, and many of the ones that were open had run out of food. In the city centre I saw a -strong convoy of army vehicles speeding towards government buildings. Across the road dozens of men queued to join the military after receiving their conscription papers. The mayor, ex-world boxing champion Vitali Klitschko, imposed a curfew from pm today to am tomorrow.  He said the metro “will be available as shelters  ”, but added: “If you need to move around the city during the curfew... you must have identication documents.” The streets of Kyiv were eerily quiet last night. Bars and cafes were shut as police cars patrolled the city centre. Ukraine’s favourite sporting son, ex-Cha striker Andriy Shevchenko, said on social media his country had gone through “many dficult times” and that its greatest asset is its “sincere and freedom-loving people”. Those citizens are praying they will soon be free of tyrant Putin. title: hours old newborns rushed makeshift
story: Hours-old newborns rushed to makesht bomb shelter as Russia attacks Ukrainian hospitalTiny newborn babies were taken to the relative safety of a makesht bomb shelter in the depths of a childrens hospital in Dnipro, amid fears of Russian attacksInstead of the warmth and safety of the neonatal clinic, the tiny tots slept in a basement Image: Dr Denis SurkovByAntony ThrowerNews Reporter:,  Feb |comments Newborn babies, some just hours old, were rushed from the safety of a neonatal unit in Ukraine to a makesht shelter to avoid Putin’s bombs.About twelve of the tiny infants were taken by brave doctors and nurses to the basement of the building in Dnipro.Inside, they were carefully cradled by staff from Dnipropetrovsk Oblast Children’s Hospital who feared for the lives of their young charges, The Sun reports.  It follows reports of other hospitals  suffering missile damage in cities under siege by heavily armed Kremlin forces.Dr Denis Surkov, , chief of the neonatal unit at Dnipropetrovsk Oblast Children’s Hospital said of the bunker: “This is the neonatal intensive care unit. In a bomb ­shelter. “Can you imagine  This is our reality.”Earlier it was reported that the oncology centre of another hospital was left in flames after Russian forces openedfireon the building.  Shocking footage shot in Melitopol, in the south east of the war-torn nation, showed heavy fire close to the hospital before explosions in the building.The site then immediately starts to burn before more gunshots are aimed at the centre - used to help those suffering with cancer - leaving dozens of bullet holes. Russian missiles are said to have destroyed a nursery where in Ukraine, with drone footage seeming to show the bodies of two adults surrounded by blood outside the building.Outraged Ukrainian Foreign Minister Dmytro Kuleba wrote on Twitter : “Today’s Russian attacks on a kindergarten and an orphanage are war crimes and violations of the Rome Statute.#“Together with the General Prosecutor’s Office we are collecting this and other facts, which we will immediately send to the Hague. “Responsibility is inevitable. Pictures were also shared of scared Ukrainian children being led down into metro systems to shelter from Russian shelling as air raid sirens sound in sombre echoes of World War Two.The UK will personally sanction Vladimir Putin and his foreign minister Sergei Lavrov after Russiaaposs brutal invasion ofUkraine , Downing Street has said.Boris Johnsontold a virtual meeting of Nato leaders that London will target the Russian President and his key ally in Moscow imminently over the Kremlinaposs “revanchist mission” to overturn the post-Cold War order. The PM also urged fellow leaders to inflict maximum pain on President Putin and his regime by ejecting Russia from the Society for Worldwide Interbank Financial Telecommunicationnetwork - something which could cripple Russia’s ability to trade with most of the world.Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Vladimir PutinWar crimesNurseriesRussia Ukraine war" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: inside terrifying evacuation kyiv homes
story: Inside terrying evacuation of Kyiv as homes hit with missiles and Russia inches closerEXCLUSIVE: Mirror reporter Andy Lines was among thousands of people who had to flee Kyiv today as Russian tanks got close to the Ukrainian capital. People left the city by car, train, bus, bike and even on footA woman and two children walk on a street after crossing the Slovak-Ukrainian border in Ubla, eastern Slovakia Image: AFP via Getty ImagesByAndy LinesChief reporter:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |comments Thousands of people fled the Ukrainian capital today as the Russian invasion continued. Mirror reporter Andy Lines was among those who had to leave Kyiv because Russian tanks were getting close to his hotel.Here he recounts his experience... It was an incredible and dramatic exodus - all to escape from war. Tens of thousands of terried people desperately inched their way towards safety. I joined those fleeing Kyiv today to avoid the horrors of the Russian invasion. They went by car, train, bus, bike and even on foot. For security reasons we had been ordered to leave Kyiv immediately as Russian tanks rolled in perilously close to our hotel. Before we left at am I had already been evacuated for fear of a missile attack into a deep underground car park - twice! It truly was an extraordinary day.  On one of the country’s busiest motorways we passed a squadron of Ukrainian tanks hiding in the verges. The Ts and Ts were waiting to repel any Russian invaders. But to see them standing there - with their commanders sitting on the top ready for action - so close to a motorway service station was particularly chilling. We had inched along mile after mile after mile on the E before reaching the MO. I’ve never seen a traffic jam like it. It was horrendous. In the first four and a half hours we covered just seven miles. There was one three hour period when our driver never once got into second gear.  It took us five hours  minutes just to get out of the city. There were rusty -year-old Ladas, tractors and brand new expensive Mercedes. Minibuses, motorbikes and giant trucks politely competed for space. But everyone knew the enormity of the situation and I only heard one angry toot of a horn during the gruelling  hours trek. All the drivers wanted to do was to reach safety for the night. Former factory worker Vasiliy, , wound down his window during one stop. He was driving his light blue battered old Lada with just one working rear brake light. He had driven in to Kyiv to pick up his son, daughter-in-law and grandchild. On his roof rack was a pushchair and a suitcase. He said: “I come from Zhytomyr in central Ukraine.“I came to pick up my son who lives in Kyiv. I came yesterday when I heard that Kyiv was shelled. “I’m glad we were able to get out and leave.” As cars edged past us they were all packed many with four or five people squeezed into the back seat. All were sombre. No-one was laughing. But despite that there was a real spirit of camaraderie. We passed the same cars on the three-lane carriageway so often that we ended up on nodding terms. Several people gave me a thumbs up and reassuring wave when they realised we were journalists.  One woman was making a cheese and tomato sandwich on her lap for her young son. She spoke no English but opened her window and signalled to ask meI’d like her to make me one as well. Many cars had children and grannies and several had pet cats and dogs. One woman had her brown pomeranian sitting in her lap in the front seat - constantly stroking it to give the dog reassurance. The unprovoked invasion of neighbouring Ukraine by Russian forces on the command of President Vladimir Putin has sparked bloodshed and chaos. With Putinaposs troops shelling cities across Ukraine and the nationaposs army vowing to fight to the death to defend their land, observers fear the death toll will be enormous.So far, it has been confirmed by President of Ukraine Volodymyr Zelensky that  civilians and military personnel were killed in the country on the first day of the Russian invasion. In an address to his people, Mr Zelensky revealed a further  had been wounded in the fighting. The death toll is set to rise as, on the night of February , Ukraine’s deputy defence minister Hanna Maliar claimed nearly , Russian servicemen had died during the first two days of the deep invasion She wrote in a Facebook post that the troops of the invading country have suffered the following lossesas of pm Friday, before going on to list up to  tanks  armoured combat vehicles of ious types  aircraft seven helicopters and , special staff she claims were among the losses suffered by Russia. Meanwhile, the official Twitter page of the Ministry of Defense of Ukraine claimed in a tweet that today the number of losses from the occupying forces of the Russian Federation is more than  thousand. These claims have not yet been independently veried. In another, a black and white spaniel sat between two young children. What was more incredible we passed thousands and thousands of people actually WALKING to safety. The Polish border may be over  miles away from Kyiv but they wanted to make a start. Carrying huge rucksacks, supermarket shopping bags and wheeling suitcases they walked along the hard shoulder.  The blue and yellow Ukraine flag fluttered on a huge advertising screen. Underneath a group of youngsters walked with their cases. At times the line of people stretched as far as the eye could see. Some stopped in lay-bys for a break and to play with their children. Ten miles out from Kyiv a group, including several women, stood at the roadside trying to hitch a lt. Then within a mile there were dozens and dozens more. I’ve never seen so many hitchhikers on a single stretch of road.  On the other side of the carriageway as we headed west several convoys of Ukrainian troops were racing back down into Kyiv ready for the fight ahead. Several of them proudly paraded the Ukrainian flag. As they drove past they received huge cheers. When we were still in Kiev, before we reached the countryside, there was a massive military presence. Along the side of the road armed camouflaged soldiers hid under netting, surrounded by green sandbags, waiting for any Russian troops heading in. Outside the Beresteiski metro station a squad of heavily armed soldiers stood on guard.  One smoked a cigarette and yawned as he spoke to an elderly woman. In the city there were queues at every cashpoint we passed. But they were nothing compared to the lines of cars at the petrol stations. They were huge and some drivers were forced to resort to pushing their vehicles to the pumps to make use of every last bit of fuel.  And there chaotic scenes at the main railway station as people clamoured to get on the last trains out. Mums, dads and children pushed to get on and most trains were absolutely crammed. Very few people wanted to stay and those who did wanted to fight. The rest fled wonderingthey would ever be able toto their homes. The journey to Lviv took  hours but it was a route for safety for so many. title: rare syndrome saw grandad pay
story: Rare syndrome that saw grandad pay fruit picker to amputate his leg with power toolA task force investigating Kalman Tals alleged murder found other case studies which had led to superficial mutilation, finger amputation, mutilation of the tongue, breasts or noseKalman Tal may have suffered from a rare syndrome Image: FacebookByGraeme Murray:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb  A grandad who died after paying more than £, to have his leg amputated with a power tool may have been suffering from a rare sydrome, it has been reported.Detectives are reportedly looking into the possibility that Kalman Tal may have been suffering from aposMajor Self Mutilationapos disorder when he allegedly asked others to cut off his leg.Fruit picker John Yalu, , was charged with murder after allegedly using a battery saw to cut his leg off, reports MailOnline.Known as MSM, the rare condition is a complication of a severe mental illness where the sufferer removes an eye, genitals or cuts off a limb section. A task force investigating Mr Talaposs alleged murder found case studies that the syndrome had led to superficial mutilation, finger amputation, mutilation of the tongue, breasts, or nose.  Mr Talaposs leg was allegedly sawed off in Queensland, Australia and he is believed to have met with Mr Yalu, from the island of Vanuatu last Friday and again after the -year-old banana picker had been out drinking at a bar on Saturday at around .am. Detectives in Queensland say Mr Tal had asked othersthey would be willing to amputate his leg his leg, before he died. While two fisherman and a doctor told the Mail Mr Tal asked themthey would carry out the task before last week. Police have yet to establisha reported ,was paid by Mr Tal for the alleged amputation.  Mr Yalu reportedly travelled with Mr Tal in the retireeaposs car to Fitzgerald Park riverfront esplanade with a circular saw in the vehicle. The men are believed to have laid out a blue tarpaulin on a grassy area where Mr Tal injected himself with a sedative. Police allege Mr Yalu amputated Mr Talaposs leg with the power tool and helped him to the car before leaving the area. Mr Tal was found bleeding to death near the Innisfail Seafood shop on the banks of a river known for its crocodiles. Get the news you want straight to your inbox every day.to one of the Mirroraposs newsletters here Police were followed by paramedics who could not revive Mr Tal after the amputation The cause of death is believed to be cardiac arrest following major blood loss. Major Self Mutilation disorder has been reported in just four of several hundred such cases. Gary Hunter, acting Inspector who is leading the investigation, was said to be consulting mental health professionals about Mr Talaposs possible condition. Police have interviewed witnesses and the dead manaposs family, who bought a house with him in south eastern Innsail. news world-news russian-tank-swerves-crush-car-"Ukraine: Miracle rescue after Russian tank collides with carByDave BurkeSenior News Reporter:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |comments Chilling footage shows a car being crushed by a Russian tank in a seemingly deliberate act on the outskirts of Kyiv.It is claimed that the huge military vehicle was being driven by Kremlin troops when the horror crash happened. Incredibly the driver, said by witnesses to be an elderly man, survived the shocking ordeal in the under-siege Ukrainian capital. The widely shared clip shows the tank, believed to be a Strela- anti-aircraft vehicle, swerve across the road into the car, which was driving in the opposite direction. After remaining still with the crushed vehicle beneath it for nearly  seconds, the tank then slowly reverses back into the road, leaving a wreckage in its wake. It is understood to have been recorded in the Obolon district of the city, where Russian forces have been advancing in the past  hours.Click here to follow our live blog with the latest updates The video, filmed from a window overlooking the road, has sparked outrage. Witness Viktor Berbash, , told AFP news agency he had rushed out of his home after hearing gunfire.He continued: I saw an armoured vehicle and there was automatic fire. And here this car, with probably an anti-aircraft gun on it, was already here.He added: Two armoured vehicles were driving along the road, and the second of them deliberately drove into the oncoming lane.  It was not by chance, it was for fun, there was no need for this. And it just ran into this car. Stopped, reversed over it again and drove on. It is unclear whether the tank was a Russian or Ukrainian military vehicle, but reports suggest that those steering it were Russian. Shocked locals were able to free the victim, but it is unclear whether he suffered any serious injuries.Among those who shared the video was political adviser Franak Viacorka, who wrote: In Ukraine, a Russian tank had driven over the civilian car. Terrying footage. My thoughts are with the people of Ukraine. Further pictures and video show the damaged black car at the road, with an elderly-looking man looking dazed but alive. Mr Viacorka posted minutes later: A Ukrainian senior man in a car hit by the Russian tank survived! Ukrainians have been urged to use Molotov cocktails to neutralise Russian invaders as desperate fighting goes into its second day. The government called on civilians to report any movement of enemy equipment and to fight back against Vladimir Putinaposs forces. It also warned peaceful citizens not to leave their homes as cities endure heavy shelling from Russian forces. The unprovoked invasion of neighbouring Ukraine by Russian forces on the command of President Vladimir Putin has sparked bloodshed and chaos. With Putinaposs troops shelling cities across Ukraine and the nationaposs army vowing to fight to the death to defend their land, observers fear the death toll will be enormous.So far, it has been confirmed by President of Ukraine Volodymyr Zelensky that  civilians and military personnel were killed in the country on the first day of the Russian invasion. In an address to his people, Mr Zelensky revealed a further  had been wounded in the fighting. The death toll is set to rise as, on the night of February , Ukraine’s deputy defence minister Hanna Maliar claimed nearly , Russian servicemen had died during the first two days of the deep invasion She wrote in a Facebook post that the troops of the invading country have suffered the following lossesas of pm Friday, before going on to list up to  tanks  armoured combat vehicles of ious types  aircraft seven helicopters and , special staff she claims were among the losses suffered by Russia. Meanwhile, the official Twitter page of the Ministry of Defense of Ukraine claimed in a tweet that today the number of losses from the occupying forces of the Russian Federation is more than  thousand. These claims have not yet been independently veried. ›An official government Twitter account this morning said: We ask citizens to inform about the movement of equipment!Make Molotov cocktails, neutralise the occupier! Peaceful residents - be careful! Do not leave the house! This morning Ukrainian TV showed instructions on how to make Molotov cocktails, which are bottles containing flammable liquid like petrol which are set alight and hurled at the enemy. The countryaposs president, Volodymyr Zelensky, said  civilians and military personnel had been killed on the first day of the Russian attack. Describing the invaders, the Ukrainian president said: “They’re killing people and turning peaceful cities into military targets. It’s foul and will never be forgiven. Mr Zelensky said the Russian militaryaposs claim it is not targeting civilian areas is a lie. news world-news sky-news-journalist-runs-cover-"Sky News crew in Ukraine run for cover as they come under fireByHollie BoneNews Reporter:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |comments This is the horrying moment that a British journalist ran for safety after coming under mortar fire during a live broadcast from Ukraine.The Sky News crews had been reporting from the southeast of the country when shells dropped from the sky. The dramatic clip shows Sky correspondent Alex Rossi scrambling for cover with his camera crews as the shelling descended in the coastal city of Berdyansk, just  miles from strategically vital city of Mariupol. After getting to safety in a nearby building, Alex told viewers: It just shows how quickly things can change here. We were outside filming. [It was] really calm. There had been shells that had come in this morning. But again, it had gone quiet, everything felt very, very normal. Follow our live blog of the Russia Ukraine conflict here  We’ve just had to come in here to take cover because there’s been incoming mortar fire. Mariupol is the most important Ukrainian port in the Azov Sea but mainly handles smaller ships between , to , tonnes deadweight, the Mail reports. But the city appears to have come under attack by Russian forces as Putin attempts to cripple the Ukrainian economy by destroying the vital shipping route. The port alongside others connected to the Avoz Sea is a major exporting route for goods such as wheat, barley and corn to Mediterranean importers including Turkey, Italy, Cyprus, Egypt and Lebanon. Russian troops have already been deployed to guard the Chernobyl nuclear reactor, launch strikes on key airbases and surrounded Kyiv on three sides as they attempt to take the city.Fears have been raised about increased levels of radiation after Russian forces took over the Chernobyl exclusion zone and disturbed the top soil, kicking up radioactive dust. The unprovoked invasion of neighbouring Ukraine by Russian forces on the command of President Vladimir Putin has sparked bloodshed and chaos. With Putinaposs troops shelling cities across Ukraine and the nationaposs army vowing to fight to the death to defend their land, observers fear the death toll will be enormous.So far, it has been confirmed by President of Ukraine Volodymyr Zelensky that  civilians and military personnel were killed in the country on the first day of the Russian invasion. In an address to his people, Mr Zelensky revealed a further  had been wounded in the fighting. The death toll is set to rise as, on the night of February , Ukraine’s deputy defence minister Hanna Maliar claimed nearly , Russian servicemen had died during the first two days of the deep invasion She wrote in a Facebook post that the troops of the invading country have suffered the following lossesas of pm Friday, before going on to list up to  tanks  armoured combat vehicles of ious types  aircraft seven helicopters and , special staff she claims were among the losses suffered by Russia. Meanwhile, the official Twitter page of the Ministry of Defense of Ukraine claimed in a tweet that today the number of losses from the occupying forces of the Russian Federation is more than  thousand. These claims have not yet been independently veried.But Russia has refuted Ukrainian officials claims that there has been any increase in gamma radiation.Speaking in a televised statement this morning, Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelensky said he was Russiaaposs number one target and feared he would be abducted in an effort to topple the countryaposs political system.  He said: “According to our information, the enemy marked me as target number one, my family as target number two.“They want to destroy Ukraine politically by destroying the head of state. We have information that enemy sabotage groups have entered Kyiv.”Zelensky is in hiding but claimed he was still in Kyiv last night as he resists fleeing his capital. “I am staying in the government quarter together with others,” he said. title: smitten man who went run
story: Smitten man who went on run with nursing home lover, , dies two days after herRalph Terry Gibbs, , took girlfriend Carol Lisle, , from the nursing home in Mandurah, Australia, and drove her , miles to bring her home - he was facing jail before he diedRalph Terry Gibbs took his girlfriend from the nursing home and drove her , miles to bring her home Image: Western Australia PoliceByAlice Peacock:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |comments A smitten pensioner who faced jail after breaking his dementia -stricken partner and going on the run with her has died just two days after his long-time love. Ralph aposTerryapos Gibbs, , took girlfriend Carol Lisle, , from the nursing home in Mandurah, Australia, and drove her , miles to bring her home.He drove her across the sweltering Outback to Queensland on January  because they could no longer be apart. The couple have been together for  years and he acted out of love after she was moved across the country by her family. Two days after they left the facility, he was found with Lisle, who has dementia and Parkinsonaposs. She reportedly was distressed when police found them deep in a desert in C heat - just  miles from the Northern Territory border dressed in the same clothes as she was in when she was first taken. And now, Ralph has been killed in a car crash, according toNine News reports.His death yesterday morning came just  hours after Carol - the love of his le - passed away in her sleep. Lisle had originally been taken to Perth by her goddaughter last year while Ralph was recovering from an illness in hospital. Earlier this month police confirmed Ralph was initially charged with deprivation of liberty and endangering le, but he pleaded guilty to a charge of unlawful detention on February . Magistrate Raelene Johnston said sentencing Gibbs was not an easy exercise after the pensioner told Perth magistrates court that he was acting out of love.  On Friday, February , said it was clear that Gibbs just wanted to be with his partner of  years but added that his actions were entirely misguided. She said: I accept that you believe you were acting out of love and that you were acting out of care for your partner and that you wanted to be with her, and you believed that she wanted to be with you. But objectively your conduct was extremely dangerous, and the objective seriousness of your offending was made clear by the reactions of those people who observed you. She went on to explain to the court that his actions were premeditated as Gibbs had purchased a car, jerry cans of petrol and a map of the country just days before. You placed your personal desire over the welfare of your partner, she added. You continued to place your wishes above her needs. You must have known you were struggling to look after her, yet you continued on your journey. Your conduct could have compromised her health. Given the extremely remote location you were found in. Johnston acknowledged that Gibbs had no previous convictions but said a jail sentence needed to be imposed despite his lawyer arguing that a fine would have been more appropriate. Gibbs fears that he will never see his partner again after it was announced he would be sentenced to seven monthsapos jail, suspended for  months, with a two-year restraining order. I have been fighting for a year to get her back so we can see each other because she has dementia and may not last much longer, he had said outside of court. title: vladimir putin yet another paranoid
story: Vladimir Putin is yet another paranoid and deranged dictator on the marchBrian Reade says Vladimir Putin is a deranged, bloodthirsty dictator who is wreaking havoc in Ukraine and Europe - and says his downfall will come when Russian people realise who he really isVladimir Putin is nothing but another deranged megalomaniac, Brian Reade says Image: via REUTERSopinionByBrian Reade:,  Feb |commentsI have a guilty pleasure which I love to indulge when I’m nursing a hangover on a cold, miserable day.It involves mugs of tea, toast and laying on the couch watching Netflix’s World War II In Colour. When the family ask why I’ve turned into a ­military fetishist excited by tanks, bombs and corpses I put them straight. And tell them I’m consuming the ­ultimate comfort dish. Because nothing lts the spirits like watching deranged, bloodthirsty dictators get their comeuppance in glorious technicolour. Sadly we’re seeing a deranged, bloodthirsty dictator wreaking havoc again, but now it’s in real-time on mainstream news. And it will be a long time before we can watch the story of Vladimir Putin ’s downfall with any comfort or joy.But come, his downfall will. ­Hopefully when enough Russian people outside of the KGB clique who now nod at his every insane proclamation about annexing Eastern Europe into a new Soviet empire, realise that he’s Adolf Hitler with Botox. Joseph Stalin with built-up heels. A shirtless Kim Jong Un flashing his sagging pecs.Another small, paranoid ­megalomaniac demanding respect from a world he despises for not recognising his ine destiny to rule however, or wherever, he wants, unopposed. We’re witnessing so many laughable attempts to brainwash the Russian people into believing he has a legitimate right to invade another sovereign state, it feels like watching Armando Iannucci’s satire The Death Of Stalin.  The meeting where he bullied his closest advisers into fearing they’ll soon be Novichocked, which we’re told took place at pm when we see a wristwatch saying pm. The staged footage of alleged Ukrainian attacks on pro-Russian sympathisers, which are so amateurish and error-strewn You’ve Been Framed should send the Kremlin £ for each comic gem.And the most risible claim of all: that Putin is invading Ukraine to liberate its people from “Nazication” when he’s the one the world is currently picking out in a Hitler identity parade.There are some in Britain who sympathise with Putin’s view that NATO’s uncompromising presence on his borders had gone too far. Others claim the EU has “poked the Russian bear” too much by ­arrogantly expanding east.  Many, like me, can’t stomach the hypocrisy of this government lambasting Putin’s abuse of power when they are funded by oligarchs and his cronies, and hate to see Boris Johnson exploit the crisis to distract from his own criminal activity at home. But that should not stop any right-minded person from seeing Putin for what he is. A deranged, rogue dictator who shares none of our values and is an existential threat to world peace. A cruel-hearted autocrat who censors his media, imprisons adversaries, crushes gay rights, poisons opponents on foreign soil and rules by fear.  A tyrant who ides the nation’s wealth up not among the people but himself and his kleptomaniac cronies whose most vocerous admirers all seem to be on the hard right: Jair Bolsonaro, Donald Trump, Marine Le Pen, Nigel Farage etc. Imprisoned Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny tweeted from his cell this week that Putin was like a “drunk grandfather” inducing “imperial hysteria” which would be funnyhe didn’t have nuclear codes in his hands. Hopefully, one day soon, we can look at his humiliating demise from our couches and laugh. title: glimmer of hope for seed tattie exports as canadian style deal is considered
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. title: farmers told to seize the day as sustainability juggernaut approaches
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. To log in please visit www.pressandjournal login.If you have any problems logging in, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on  , or email.When you purchased your subscription, an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.No, your existing reoccurring billing agreement will not change. If you cancel this agreement you can still purchase a new subscription in the future through The Press and Journal website. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The Evening Express website is no longer available. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Evening Express branded newsletters. You will now receive Press and Journal newsletters. If you do not wish to receive these, click the #unsubscribe# link at the bottom of the newsletter email.The Press and Journal has a Web subscription available which will give you access to all content on site from The Press and Journal and the Evening Express. You can purchase a PJ Web or PJ ePaper subscription here: www.pressandjournal subscribeThe Evening Express ePaper subscription is still available for purchase here.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.No, there is only one Web subscription available on The Press and Journal. The Press and Journal Web subscription will give you access to all content on site from The PJ and the Evening Express. You can purchase a Press and Journal Web or Press and Journal ePaper subscription here.If you have an existing Evening Express Web subscription then all your subscription benefits are now available on The Press and Journal site. You have access to a bigger and better website, with all your favourite Evening Express content plus more.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.You can purchase an Evening Express ePaper subscription here.Yes, you can. Our ePapers are an exact digital replica of the newspaper and carry unique content in both titles.
